comments.text: Great idea! Indeed for this challenge understanding decision making is key. Related to this talk is the talk by Barry Schwartz: also a TED video http://www.ted.com/talks/barry_schwartz_on_the_paradox_of_choice.htmlrelated inspirations: why don't people donate? http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-number-of-bone-marrow-donors-to-help-save-more-lives/inspiration/why-don-t-people-donate-american-red-cross-how-to-overcome-the-emotional-response-to-needles./or being a donor as a default option (based on Schwartz' work): http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-number-of-bone-marrow-donors-to-help-save-more-lives/inspiration/being-a-donor-as-a-default-option-easing-the-burden-of-choice/

comments.text: I was about to suggest same inspiration, but fortunately I found the search bar first. Anyway, here's a short video clip explaining how Kiva works for those who are unfamiliar with the concept: http://vimeo.com/16991128

This is great, especially for patients that are under-represented in the donor database.  Creating a story that ties you not only to a very specific person, but also a culture (or multi-culture) that you might share some kinship with, that would seem to be very powerful.

Love this Haiyan. There is nothing more rewarding than seeing the success stories of Kiva recipients that you and/or your friends have lent to. Would love to follow the stories of transplant recipients in the same way.

Thanks Sarah! I think Kiva shows up in almost every challenge :) You know what, I totally agree with your point about privacy issues.One direction might be stories that focus on successful treatment, with patients who agree to being interviewed or featured.

Great inspiration Halyan! I strongly believe in the impact of personal stories and human connection... Although there might be some concerns related to privacy issues (that could be stronger in the medical field than in microfinance maybe...).

donate_with_a_smile.description: Our concept is a quiz that matches you with a person who has previously received a bone marrow donation. This quiz connects you based on personality, background, age, and interests. By learning about this marrow patient, you'll forge a stronger personal connection, and be happy to donate. Learning details about this match and conveying the information in a way that it relates to personal experience of potential donors can help to increase the number of donors by removing misunderstandings surrounding donation and thus spreading the word.

comments.text: Great concept Varun! I'm impressed by the time and thought that you and your friend Nathan put into this! And I could definitely see this as a downloadable mobile app - a quick quiz to learn more about bone marrow donation and people whose lives have been saved. Nice job!

I think you nailed the barriers right on the head. The emotional barrier is the greatest one of all, not the technical difficulties that accompany it. Thanks for sharing this concept and putting so much work into it.

Thanks so much for being willing to share your experience and insights with us Eva! You brought up a lot of good ideas, that we'll surely be thinking about. I believe there are concepts being posted that address some of your points, and I just posted one to follow-up on your thoughts about naming, misperception, & fear ( http://bit.ly/ht6tns ). irrational_and_subconscious_fears.description: Perspective of someone who would not donate
irrational_and_subconscious_fears.creator: 25c328e1221ccdc804d5c969f4124652

comments.text: I can totally relate to this Joris. Pricking my skin to give blood is one thing, but for some reason anything beyond that makes my skin crawl.Andrea - I think you're on to something with communication by regular people. In some ways the lab coats are just as frightening, but to hear the story from someone  "like me" is comforting.

Do you think it would help for potential donors to connect somehow (video's or written) with people who have already donated?  It could be part of FAQ, but tailored to these particular issues and concerns.  A "in your own words" response, but not live.As common themes emerge, in this challenge, key questions will become more obvious.  These questions could be answered by professional medical people, as well as people "just like me".  It can help a lot to hear from regular people who have "been through it".  While not the whole story, it can help.I think we all have fears about things like this, whether spoken or not.

Thanks for sharing your own experiences and insights Joris! You're very right that fear is a big motivator to not do something - and any potential Concepts we come up with later on definitely need to address these fears. In the spirit of providing some information to help ease your fears, I checked out the Be The Match website to get some more information. When you donate peripheral blood stem cells (PBSC), the blood-forming cells that are removed during donation actually regenerate over the following 4-6 weeks. When you donate actual bone marrow, the same thing happens - the marrow also regenerates within 4-6 weeks.If you're curious to learn more, check out this page on Be The Match's site: http://www.marrow.org/DONOR/When_You_re_Asked_to_Donate_fo/Steps_of_Donation/index.html
Great point about fears Joris. Thanks for your willingness to share this with us. Krassimira, sounds like your interview notes would be a great separately posted inspiration as well!

Thanks for agreeing with me Krassimira :) For me personally, all of the points you named are issues and we probably need to form honest answers to these questions/fears if we want people to actually donate. In general one of the biggest fears people have, is a fear of uncertainty.

Joris, I agree with you that fears need to be addressed....Yesterday I interview some of my colleagues. There was a bone marrow registration campaign in my company and all of them registered. 2 of them received a letter later on that they are a potential match and they refused to donate as they were SCARED....They feared: 1) anethesia and how will the body respond to that 2) surgery, especially as they never underwent full anethesia surgery 3) possible infection 4) uncertianty would their bone marrow really save a life? The rest of the folks I interviewed agreed that although they registered they're scared of the intervention and if they're an actual match, they would most probably not donate....

irrational_and_subconscious_fears.title: Irrational and subconscious fears

expose_the_shocking_truth.description: A recent ad campaign to increase Hepatitis B awareness relies on high-impact tactics.  One ad in particular shows ten beauty queens in a pageant photo, each with sash and glowing smile.  The text asks us, “Which one deserves to die?”
expose_the_shocking_truth.creator: 78842815248300fa6ae79f7776a5080a

good_will_stores_in_s._asian_countries.description: Introduce "Good Will" stores that give incentives to people to donate in rural sectors.
good_will_stores_in_s._asian_countries.creator: 7f82ce618eb3b2f2d40300a2916de3f0

comments.text: Indeed Jaskeerat  you made a great call to action! Guess I'm just wary of alienating discussion with South Asians who feel that we're misrepresenting their countries of origin and misleading folks who may be unclear of the texture local issues. But some great thoughts here from your end  you got applause from my end :^)

Hi Meena, thanks for your comment. I agree my call for the percentage was a little exaggerated, but the idea was to drive across the essential requirement of the Indian s. We feel that we should be rewarded for every little thing that we do, so why not have a system where we help ourselves by helping others. A system like this may work for people in the lower as well as middle class, something like the Ration system. My target was to catch hold of this % of population. But ill check up on my stats...before i post! :)

Hi Jaskeerat  great call to think about outreach to rural communities. Am just a bit concerned about your poverty line stats (as someone of Indian ethnic origin) Although stats differ depending on where you're culling them form  they generally fall between 28 and 55% for those below the poverty line in India. Perhaps you got confused with rural dwellers who are often pitched around the 70-75% mark? Though worth keeping in mind that they're a diverse bunch and include many middle and upper class folks too. Bangladesh is an entirely different context and is not usually joined together with stats for India. But some excellent thoughts on your post aside from this :^)

good_will_stores_in_s._asian_countries.title: Good Will stores in S. Asian Countries

comments.text: Hi Vincent,Great idea. 23andMe could build partnerships with the bone marrow registries for cross promotion in return for offering a discount to users who do chose to opt in to having their type added to the registry. People already in the registry are likely to fit the profile of potential 23andMe customers, so it could be a great investment in lead generation (not to mention the positive social impact). 23andMe charges a monthly fee, so the discount could be one year free.
Hey Vincent, this is a great inspiration! The curiosity to find out more about our DNA could be linked to a voluntarily bone marrow donor registration.

human_library_of_experiences.description: Imagine you could have a chat with someone who once donated, or someone who can tell you about all the stages of the process, or someone who can tell you how their life changed after finding a donor. What if there was a human library that could let you have these conversations?
human_library_of_experiences.creator: 1c65d27eacabad9b279d948bbf96f262

comments.text: Hey, thanks for the positive comments!I'm afraid I've been caught busy on a project these last few days and never got a chance to add the human library to the food challenge inspiration, my apologies for not acting on your great and lovely suggestion quicker :( Sarah, I love that you've added the social media aspect to the concept, I think I'd you could somehow see a link to the person who's experience you can learn from it's even more powerful! Maybe it could even be embedded as an profile option on sites such as Facebook? Really like the added dimension, thanks a million!

Hey Susan, I think this concept is also a great inspiration for the new Local Food challenge. Could you add it to the inspiration phase there as well. One of the issues we're asked to look at is the strength of inter-generational and intercultural knowledge sharing. The Human Libraries can be excellent for sharing knowledge about food as well. Obviously, I can also add this as an inspiration, but then I get the DQ points. So, might be nicer if you do it :)

face time is one of the greatest tools in creating change. i also really like the element of maintaining relationships, whether they be anonymous or not. it helps create the very real human connection that is needed in sensitive areas such as this one.

Perhaps you could add in social networking. I've seen on a number of websites where it tells me my other facebook friends that have liked a specific story or something from that site. If you could see that your friend had a video story maybe it would help to make it more personal; or on LinkedIn a 2nd connection, 3rd connection etc.Another option might be an android/iphone app or something that could look through your contacts and pair up if any of them had a story to share.
I like the idea of human libraries! This concept also connects well with the one from Johan: informal group storytelling meetings - http://3bl.me/ghmeq2

human_library_of_experiences.title: Human library of experiences

art_and_awareness_.description: Public art can be used as a means to spread awareness while creating community enrichment.
art_and_awareness_.creator: 6e1c9e9b0acf4094070bdf1033bd4cd2

comments.text: Hi Andrea,I like the idea of public art installation. I agree you could have both a series of physical installations in different places of the cities and / or in different cities like the elephant models in London last year (http://www.viewlondon.co.uk/whatson/model-elephants-in-london-feature-2884.html).I also think that merging it with digital version of it could be great. I've done something around online interactions with an artist two years ago: building_space_with_words (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aKi1bHw1smo) and we have thought of more interactive versions of this. I also like the idea of storytelling you mentioned in your last comment. It reminded me of this video "fifty people, one question": http://fiftypeopleonequestion.com/films/3-brooklyn-ny

Hi Andreayes, agree with the others about the auctioning idea. People will see the art pieces, publicitiy will rise around them and then people will be wanting one. The hearts in San Francisco are great as they change fairly frequently. Have you seen my 'B isn't just for Beer' concept and 'Jones Soda and M&Ms' - they might make nice builds ;-) Both are concepts looking at using bottles as a medium for showing bone marrow awareness art - similar ideas.

Joanna, thanks for the push to flush out the idea; you've got some great questions!  I've updated the concept above in response. I'm not quite sure how, but I think that there is a real possibility for this project to work in digital media into physical art installations.  Potentially QR codes at installation's location so people can see the art's "match" in real time on their cell phone?  Or using the QR codes to pull up inspirational stories of donor/recipients?

Great idea, Andrea.  I particularly like the idea of auctioning off the art after it's on display in order to raise money for the registry!  I'd love to see how you could push this further:  Any ideas on what sort of physical form it could take?  What sort of events or other engagement/discussion tactics would flow naturally from public art about bone marrow donation?  Like the quilt squares and the cows, is there a way to make tons of them that are both identifiable and unique?  Or, like the quilt, could there be a way for individuals to contribute their own creations?  Thanks for fueling my thinking with this concept!
Andrea, terrific idea! Public art is such a unique and powerful way to raise awareness. And Sam, I'm loving the idea of pop-up art installations for bone marrow!

Could be a really nice idea, just should look out that it doesnt become over bearing, and common place within society, might cause people to become pretty depressed, maybe feature it as a pop up art thing?

art_and_awareness_.title: Art and Awareness

swab_a_cheek_and_get_your_dna_transforme.description: The company DNA Art offers a way to represent your DNA in a piece of art- a poster, picture, postcard. Such type of art is one-of-a kind. How about designing a campaign that provides an unique piece of art to the donor based on his/her DNA?
swab_a_cheek_and_get_your_dna_transforme.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: Fantastic idea, Krassimira! We live in a design-age, and if the artworks can be fine-tuned by designers, and used as wallpaper on computers, phones, posters, or anything of the like, a positive association with donating can be achieved.
Awesome idea Krassimira. Inspired me to post a related one: http://bit.ly/ffPTnJ
Ashley, I think it would be worth trying to see if they could offer a DNA artwork at a reduced price of the user registers as a donor- I sea a potential campaign here...

This would be cool!  And also interesting in that currently the HLA data that is seen in the lab is often very primitive -numerical data, or line graphs that have to be interpreted by a keen eye and experienced mind.   It would be cool to design some infographics that would be both useful in a lab analysis setting, and beautiful up on your wall.
I second Ashley's comment! Great inspiration, now I really want to have one of those DNA posters on my wall :)

This is so great! And also amazing to think that this company is collecting DNA from people, and according to their FAQ section, destroying the DNA after creating the art. Wonder if they'd ever offer a reduced fee on the DNA artwork, for instance, if the consumer were willing to be placed on a bone marrow registry!

swab_a_cheek_and_get_your_dna_transforme.title: Swab a Cheek and Get your DNA transformed in a piece of art...

comments.text: Very smart way to raise awareness of bone marrow to the second largest population in the world!

Great concept! Smart to leverage a very popular sport in such a way, and incorporate social networking in real life in it as well! Very impressive. This could also be easily reused in all the many countries in the world where cricket is popular. The Indian professional league would be a good place to start, because that has a global audience as well.

from_cricket_to_a_cure.title: From Cricket to a Cure

helping_people_choose.description: So bone marrow matches aren't quite a donor-initiated selection process, but building on Louise's dating site idea, I was thinking of peer-to-peer lending site Zopa.com. The nice thing about this site is it allows people to browse and select borrowers they want to donate to. How might we allow donors to, if not select, then understand their recipients in a deeper way?
helping_people_choose.creator: 7771fbb20af6ef10827c593daa3aff7b
helping_people_choose.title: Helping people choose

health_badges.description: Using Badges on social networking sites that display donation status could turn the experience into a game, where collecting points equates to donating marrow, blood, organs, etc.
health_badges.creator: 3ea6277babd0570c650fca3d17ec4bc5

comments.text: Nice, love how badge collection translates to repeat and cross donations.
This is great - this social impact should't be underestimated!

health_badges.title: Health Badges

pass_it_on_build_awareness_through_crypt.description:
"Be my match.  Tag.  You're it.  Pass it on."
A wallet-sized business card that can be handed from friend to friend, encouraging the reciever to visit the website, learn about the process, and register.  Signed by everyone who has received the card before and paired with a cryptic message and 2D barcode, the card can peak the reciever's curiosity and encourage them to join bandwagon along with their friends.
pass_it_on_build_awareness_through_crypt.creator: 3f32b2195862ccd25fbdca50bfb96e9a

comments.text: I love this idea - it's simple, cost-effective, and unobtrusive. You just pass the card to someone you know and continue on your merry way!! I think the mystery on the card is enough of a reason to look up what you've just been handed. The more circles of people we could get this idea into, the better.Have you ever heard of geocaching? It's a GPS scavenger hunt that is literally all over the world. I met up with an old friend in Bangkok, and we randomly spent the afternoon exploring and geocaching. We used his handheld GPS to locate the coordinates of a specific geocache box given on their website, and we covertly searched under a few rocks near a tree. Everyone who ever finds each specific box adds something small so they can take something small. As evidence of how random these boxes are, I believe we left a keychain and funny quote and took a tiny plastic jack-in-the-box! I bet if we could get a social movement going to leave these cards in geocaches all over the world, we could easily reach people worldwide!http://www.geocaching.com/
Hi Nancy, loved the concept again when re-reading it for evaluation. Thought it might also be nice to have an option on the website for people to print out or order cards.
agreed! the more cards the better!

Thanks Vincent.  I really appreciate it.  On another note, while evaluating this concept myself, I realized that one of the flaws is attach rate once a person gets to the website.  One idea I have floating around is that we can continue the puzzle on the first splash screen on the website.  The user can be quizzed.  After answer a couple questions they can see how they did and learn and perhaps even see they had some misconceptions about the process.  This helps people learn even before know what the website is about.  Maybe only after they finish the quiz and see their results do we show them the register button.  :)  Seems like that will work!

Just updated screenshots with the breadcrumb of the card & realized that it could be used as a little chat / comment room for those that have questions of just want to leave a fun note.  I'll need to find a way to let people opt out of location but still get counted.  I don't think people will like strangers they pass this card to know where they live.
I love it! Simple, yet mysterious enough to give it that extra umphf to be extraordinarily effective.

Thanks Arjan.  This project is getting more and more fun.  It feels like something like this is pretty managable and fairly low cost.  I'll draw up 2 more of the supporting ideas and add it to the concept:  a)  The tracking website to show the breadcrumb of the card b) concept for what to do with the cards.  Thanks everyone!
Nancy, the location idea and travel history is brilliant. Visualized on a map, of course. I really like this idea more and more.
Hi, nice idea, hadn't seen it before, have added it as a related concept to my social networking site. I think it's great that it's nerdy - pick a niche and win it! (plus I'm a nerd)

Sounds great.  I'll mock up putting the URL in, see how it looks, & will update the idea to make it more accessible.  On what to do with the card:  the bookcrossing website made me think how cool it would be to see the trail of places your card has been and how people have signed up because of it.  This can all be captured digitally and when you sign up you can see your very card's own digitial footprint across the city/world.  At the end of the day, it seems like that's the more intersting information than the card itself.  (Looks like a possible extension to this idea!)Random poll:  So whenever Costco or Safeway has those donation drives & they make you put your name on a paper that they post on the wall, I never really look at them and I could care less if they were there or not.  I kind of dred it when that time of the year comes around & I want to get out of the store as soon as possible.  Seems like a better use of the cards would be to have them all sent to one place & have an artist make an art piece out of them, no?  That way, it could be appealing to look at, could be kept at the hospital for years on end, and would promote awareness.

I think a url like tagyourit.net would be good to put on the card to make it more accessible. And about full cards: I'm a strong proponent of  global localization, so to speak. Would it be an idea to have an address to mail the card to where it will be scanned to be put on a website and also maybe have some local hospitals or public places where the cards will be displayed physically.Back to the website part: I think http://bookcrossing.com is an interesting example. Maybe it can be combined into the card. So that online the travels of the cards, and the new registered donors connected to it, can be followed.

I do like this idea, you are using a common form of interface (the business card) a newer form of communication (the barcode) and adding personalisation with the signatures. And the 'tag - you're it' line makes it a playful challenge. Great work!

Yes, that is the weakness of this current design.  It only caters to folks with smart phones.  However, those that do have smart phones can sign up immediately and not have to wait until they get home.   Do you think putting a URL on the card to cater to different audiences will take away from the design at all?  Folks w/o smart would would need to google it to solve the myster.  Another idea I had was to have these be USB enabled business cards but feared that would drive up the cost.  Thanks!

I like this idea. Although the assumption of a business card being used for this design can restrict the outreach of this concept. You might want to think of some medium which is probably more acceptable within a wider audience. Great job

Thanks for all the feedback.  I'm hoping that because the card is signed and folks see that others have taken the card to heart & registered, that those who receive it will not just throw it away.  Hopefully, they'd at least continue to pass it on even if they don't think the right decision for themselves.  Does anyone have any interesting ideas on what someone should do with the card once it's full?
I will definitely look forward to hearing about how we can get these business cards to distribute.

I agree with Vincent, definitely an intriguing idea. Tag. You're it. That will stick to in mind. I'm about to order new business cards, maybe I can do something with this. I especially like the QR code idea!
Intriguing idea! =)

pass_it_on_build_awareness_through_crypt.title: Pass it on - Build awareness through cryptically signed cards passed from friend to friend

py/tuple: How easy is this concept to implement?
I could start right now.
This might take a bit of planning and probably some help from several partners.
This is a big undertaking and I'd need a lot of help from friends, organizations and other groups to make it happen.
Will this concept successfully reach and encourage under-represented populations (including South Asians) to join the bone marrow registry?
Yes, this concept will resonate with diverse groups of people from all over the world.
No, this concept might not reach under-represented populations very well.
I'm not sure, but I hope so!
How well does this concept dispel myths, ease fears, or provide education about bone marrow registration and donation?
Really well -- I already feel like I have a better understanding of the process and why it's important.
Okay, though it'll still take some explaining to get people to understand how bone marrow registration and donation work.
Not very well -- we'd have to create a highly detailed plan around this concept to help people understand.
How scalable is this concept?
This concept is highly scalable and could easily impact people all over the world.
This concept is really best suited for small groups and local areas.
This concept could be scaled, but we'd have to refine it for different settings.

sweeten_the_deal_the_swab_becomes_a_loll.description: Watching someone with the bone marrow swab reminded me of someone eating a lollipop. What if the swab broke in 2 and one end was a lollipop. So you get a sweetener in the deal.
sweeten_the_deal_the_swab_becomes_a_loll.creator: e271b7c6ed709feca8776fd4f9b91e86

comments.text: oh my. this is a MUST to be included in any of the other concepts... too doable... to easy... :) well played Haiyan.
I'm hoping the Stanford kids will make a sweet prototype. Thanks Sina for putting in a good word.
Sweet and simple!
Thanks Jung!

Great! Have you thought about teaming up with the Swab Squad?? :) http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-number-of-bone-marrow-donors-to-help-save-more-lives/concepting/the-swab-squad-red-stick/

Brilliant idea, Halyan! It reminds me of how the Jewish children, during the Middle Ages, used to learn the Hebrew alphabet: the letters of the alphabet was written on a slate and covered with honey; the child then licked the slate with his tongue so that the words of the Scriptures might be "as sweet as honey". This positive association is a powerful tool to change people's perceptions.
This is simply brilliant Halyan. I love it. I've talked about it to friends and they all reacted the same.

I love this idea!  What if we handed out these lollipops at my Party with a Purpose: Bone Marrow event where after learning about how easy it is, and hearing families speak about what happened when someone didn't donate people would be inspired to finish their lollipops and register leaving the swab behind?  How fantastic would this be.

Agreed.  This is a fun way to associate fond memories with a good act.  The lollipop / q-tip can also come with a story from a child who is battling a blood cancer.  Have a lollipop to help a child... strong message.
Nice concept! Really like the idea of combining a reward directly with the action of registering.

sweeten_the_deal_the_swab_becomes_a_loll.title: Sweeten the Deal - The swab becomes a lollipop

hollywood_for_bone_marrow_donation.description:
Anyone of you saw the (great and inspiring) movie Seven Pounds with Will Smith?
Then I am sure you remember the scene in which Ben painfully donates Bone Marrow to help a sick kid. That scene made me awfully afraid of BM Donation.

My idea:
Reverse that negative impression! Why not cooperate with Hollywood and do POSITIVE "product placement" for our case?
hollywood_for_bone_marrow_donation.creator: 4a0b0f0e7ff5dc7324234413a08219d6

comments.text: Thanks to Ashley for motivating me to elaborate my concept a bit more!

hollywood_for_bone_marrow_donation.title: Hollywood for Bone Marrow Donation

next_time_you_make_a_b_day_present_make_.description:
Searching for a one-of-a-kind birthday present? 
Next time you make a b-day present, think of a Hero Gift Certificate + Registration Kit.
A friend of mine mentioned today at lunch that she gave her husband as a b-day present a “Hero Gift Certificate” and a registration kit for bone marrow donation.
next_time_you_make_a_b_day_present_make_.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: What a beautiful concept! This is a great idea. Could see this almost being a process to get you from registering to donating. You become hero for registering, and something even higher for actually donating, creating a circle of luminaries for those who have actually donated. Nice work!
Thanks, Jennifer!
Nikhil, you're so right...this could have tremendous resonance amongst kids....
Love it. Would focus on Kids.They have 'Pester Power'. Plus exchanging notes in school about what each other got as a gift would really spread the message.

Larry, thanks for your comments! I do think this is a "low hanging fruit" to 1) get more people to register 2) make it a personal committment. This could be coupled with a campign "Next time you make a present, make it a life saving one!"

Love it!  This would be so easy to implement, the NMDP already has an online site to register and get a kit in the mail, so the infrastructure is there, its just turning it from a 'procedure' into a 'gift'.  brilliant!

Thanks, Katie and Vincent! The gift certificate comes with a call for action, which is very powerful and creates a ripple effect as well. And Katie, you're right - what a cooler present than that?! Excited to see how my friends will react to such a present.
Great idea. It's like those gift donation cards, but now it encourages increased donation action from the gift recipient as well.
Love it. Fantastic idea. As another play on this, two of my brothers and my fiance have both given me the present of registering themselves. I couldn't have asked for a cooler present.

what_s_up_doc.description: Build trust and break down fear barriers by integrating Marrow donation literature and swab kits into local doctor's offices. By reaching out to local physicians, we might be able to convert more potential donors. It will drive awareness, put people in a position to learn more about the donation procedure, and potentially put the myths to bed.
what_s_up_doc.creator: 2fe9fbde5ee72e9fa725278585328741

comments.text: In the concept I posted I am having a different theory. I feel donors who are skeptical about donation process may not be very confident even if a doctor tries to convince them. It's like psychologically they know it's a doctors job to convince them and they may feel a doctor would do anything to convince them. For example if I am going to a doctor and doctor tells me it wont be painful I might not take it that seriously as I know the doctor tells this to everybody. So my theory is that if people try to connect with others who have gone through the same experience then they would feel more confident about the donation process. Great work Michael. Your work helped to make a point about my theory without working on a example myself. Thx

Thanks for the comments! Arjan, the "Opt out" concept is awesome. The idea of incorporating marrow registration as a standard on all medical forms at the very least will get the conversation going and put everyone in a position to learn about it face to face with a medical professional.Vincent - thanks for the link back to your original concept. Mine's looking a bit redundant now, but at least we're on the same page. I love your idea about incentivizing donation through insurance benefits!
Agreed that trusted medical advisors could really help here. Posted some related thoughts earlier that I think you might be interested in: http://bit.ly/g3iH1U
Yes! Of course, the doctor/general practitioner. I forgot about that in my Opt out when you're tested concept. See http://3bl.me/cgpqd5 I'll link this one. Could be a powerful combined concept.

comments.text: Great to hear about partnering with blood banks!  If consent is given during a blood drive, you basically just need to take one more vial of blood, incrementally almost zero extra effort on everyone's part.  I think there is already a concept on opt-out vs opt-in, this would be the perfect venue for this extra vial -> bone marrow matching to be an opt-out choice.
I liked the idea of a follow-up and the image of a facebook page is a great inspiration for a future concept!
Hi Priya. Was musing about how blood drives and marrow donor registration could be very complementary. Excited to discover through your post how this is actually happening on the ground right now!

pop_culture_creates_pop_action.description: Get TV shows, especially those that are medically based like House, Gray's Anatomy, Private Practice, Royal Pains, etc, to have a show that highlights the need for bone marrow donors, with an appeal from a cast member at the end of the show.  If they could all do it in November, Bone Marrow Awareness Month, that might really up awareness.
pop_culture_creates_pop_action.creator: a1e991dcff2a10a49b8e765d1ea4a0ee

comments.text: I had similar idea as well. In some episodes of House they talk about bone marrow donation ( I remember at least 3 times). In all of them patient refuses to have their relatives donate because they are scared about the operation and after effects. Instead scenarios should demonstrate that its a simple and harmless procedure. Such subtle promotion would work well. Not only Nike shoes and Apple computer should be promoted, right?
Jordan, I think this is a great idea. I hear some of my colleagues talk over lunch about Gray's Anatomy and this could have a great educational effect.
great idea! glad i could inspire you :)

Great idea, I was thinking of something similar, and thought I'd add on to your post.  It's also possible to further target specific populations by strategically targeting shows.  For instance, certain minority groups are underrepresented in bone marrow registries, you could target more specific shows that draw higher minority audiences, etc.  Anecdotally, there have been other examples of health-related interventions being woven into telenovelas for the hispanic population.  Or public service announcements being shot in a telenovela type way to increase public awareness.  I remember a friend telling me about these, and they seemed to generate high awareness metrics.  November is also one of the sweeps months, which is when advertisers focus on ratings to choose ad buys, and which is why shows tend to get super exciting during Nov and Feb.  This may make it more difficult to induce specific shows to go into a bone marrow plot line, if it doesn't flow with the rest of their november sweeps plotlines.  But if successful in getting onto the show, you can be sure there will be much higher exposure for bone marrow drives.

Nice Jordan. You've really thought through how to implement integration into medical TV shows. The House plotline example fits right in, and the idea to have real life donors/recipients guest star and make appeals at the end of shows is ingenious. Thanks for another strong contribution!

Great idea. And a website listed for info to register would definitely be a necessity. And with the quick amount of time an ad has, we just need them to go online to start registering, they can find out more info there. And when it comes to registering, it seems like a much easier task, than using "donate" as a key word, to those who would catch these ads.

Great idea. And a website listed for info to register would definitely be a necessity. improve_current_support_system.description: Provide adequate support to bone marrow registers in order to increase the number of actual donors when matched.
improve_current_support_system.creator: 59054561fe9b4dddd6fbec03ad0d1184

comments.text: A friend of mine mentioned that at the Bundeswehr (the German military) everyone who donated blood got 1/2 a day off. This was a great incentive to the soldiers as the the time off they usually got was not that much.

Hi Krassimira, thank you for your comment. From what I understand, contractors usually do not get paid when they don't work, or sometimes they are employed by their own recruitment consultancy that sourced them to the client's company, so they should get leaves from the agency. Ideally, employer should made it explicitly that it will not affect contractor's employability if they decide to take a fews days off because of the donation, but I can see this may be fine in principle but hard to implement. A general awareness raising in the business communities is much needed to implement this change.

Chloe, excellent point! I beleive this is a must for companies to support the donors if they have to go through surgery. One way could be to have an official medical leave for 3 days, issued by the hospital, for example. The 3 day leave shall not affect employee's salary. Not sure how this could be regulated for people who work on contractual basis....Any thoughts?

improve_current_support_system.title: Improve current support system

taking_the_bone_out_of_marrow.description: This idea builds on a lot of others, and focuses on re-branding bone marrow as well as making increasing the scope and ease of registration with a dash of product placement.
taking_the_bone_out_of_marrow.creator: c69eb8f88ca9e9fea014cb0179136086

comments.text: Thanks for the input Jennifer and Jane, you both make a very could point, a better understanding of what the donation process looks like should be included.

Removing the misconception around the kinds of bone marrow donation is crucial for engaging more potential donors, great idea Alexis. I do agree with Jennifer that you definitely want to communicate that bone marrow and PBSC donations are serious commitments that require more time and financial giving than blood donations. Perhaps focusing on creating awareness around PBSC donations instead of bone marrow donations might be more effective way to removing the fear. First you would wonder what PBSC is, and also you wouldn't directly associate it with bone marrow. Emphasizing its similarity to a plasma donation may help change perception as well.

Taking "bone" out to reduce fear... brilliant.  Now it just sounds like donating blood.  Of course there's a caveat -- it hurts a LOT more than donating blood!  So if we take the "bone" out to get more people interested, we still have to be open and honest about what the procedure entails and how it is actually quite different from donating blood.  Here's where some statistics on how many people have donated marrow (not just registered to donate, but actually donated) might help?

taking_the_bone_out_of_marrow.title: Taking the bone out of marrow

comments.text: My mother just emailed me from India really excited as she had seen this advertised there while on holiday and thought I'd be interested due to our Bone Marrow Challenge. focus_on_maximizing_the_number_of_transp.description: Some of the most tragic stories that come out of the bone marrow match process are those where a match was found, but the potential donor chose not to donate.  I bet an ongoing storytelling effort following cheek swabbing would reduce this effect.
focus_on_maximizing_the_number_of_transp.creator: da6f1750675ad329339448ec6dec0679

comments.text: This was the exact same thing i thought about. Storytelling is a good way of keeping in touch with the cause.Also regular statistical updates and medical breakthroughs via newsletters would be an interesting option.

Thanks Andy for sharing this. I think story telling/sharing is an great way to engage people. In addition to email and social network, engaging the communities of donors via face to face may work well too, esp in areas when technology is not as advanced. Just like people organize meet ups to share their travel stories organized by travel agencies, bone marrow advocacy group can also organize similar activities to share stories. The agency can recruit volunteers or activists (e.g. bone marrow receivers and their families or successful donors) to organize "meet ups" in their communities once a month or once a quarter to swap stories, share inspirations and provide support to each other. And these events then can be recorded and digitalized and uploaded which then add to the richness of the collective stories.

Great idea!  I signed up years ago and all I got was a card (which I lost), and a yearly newsletter (which I glanced at).  There must be so many better ways to keep potential donors engaged and get them excited about the possibility of helping.
Inspiring direction! Love it. There are good ideas waiting to happen here...

I think this is a great idea. On the opposite side of a story like that, I signed up as a marrow donor during grad school in 1996 because I saw a story on some TV new show about this happening to Anissa Ayala. (Remember the couple who had another baby in hopes that the baby would be a match for their daughter Anissa? The baby was a match. Early 90s timeframe.) I was motivated to register because of the story of a registrant not donating. I couldn't fathom someone receiving a call to donate and saying no.
Great conversion of the either or (maximize registrations vs maximize commitment) to yes and (get registration and then build commitment). Love it Andy!

Storytelling is such an effective tool in the effort to engage more people and prevent them from not following through. It would be so inspiring to see the stories of people who have donated... Fantastic idea.
What a great idea! This keeps people in touch with what they signed up for. As you say, using email and the social web this could be very effective.

comments.text: Great inspiration Reggie!I think you're touching one point that is very important in driving behavior towards donor registration. It is called "social validation": I am more likely to do something that my trusted ones have done, in fact, as you say, I'll feel akward if everybody is doing it and I don't.What about bringing a mechanism to let me know, let's say, who among my friends in facebook have registered as bone marrow donors and make very visible among them that I haven't. Likewise all my contacts will know when I become a registered donor.

Interesting example Katie. It's interesting because it seems like they've provided a campaign building kit. Do you know what the results of this was? Also, I'd be interested to know what mediums they used to promote this campaign.In general, I think any examples like this where you're trying to get one person to contribute to the greater good are worth studying as inspirations for increasing bone donor registrations.

Fantastic inspiration Reggie! Love the parallels to bone marrow donation in this --  normative messaging is certainly powerful and the reason why I personally think so many movements are successful. Makes me of the "no idle" campaign that Canada has = http://oee.nrcan.gc.ca/transportation/personal/idling.cfm

oh thats cool how do I do that?

Oh, I think that as a concept it is very valuable to look at. The concept being to focus also on alternatives to registered donors. In the end what counts is not the number of registered donors, but the number of people helped. A paradigm shift is a helpful concept!

I think there was a TED talk about this in the inspiration phase. I like the thinking behind it, and it seems like very promising technology. I think it would be great to have both live-donors and printed organs as a possibility. Increases the chances of survival for patients.

"Hi, I'm _____.  My favorite hobby is _________.  Are you my match?"
A website that lets potential donors put a human face to the recipient database by showcasing short video stories from actual potential receipiants that are personal and fun, showing people that they are no different from the people who have this condition.
be_my_match_hear_their_stories._meet_the.creator: 3f32b2195862ccd25fbdca50bfb96e9a

comments.text: Hi, This reminded me of adoption profiles - http://www.adoptionconnection.org/adoptive_parent_profiles.php - I think it's a really great idea to make a real connection and build empathy like this. I think building empathy is one of the biggest things we can do to motivate people to register.

Thanks for the feedback.  Yeah, I think this would cater to folks like me who don't really like reading websites because I'm a bit lazy.  I'd rather have someone just tell me what to do.  If interspersed with some of these we could have testimonials from those that actually registered, it might help encourage folks that are on the fence as well.   The key to all the videos though, is that they need to be fun & uplifting.  I think once it gets too sad & I'm afraid folks will just get turned away.
Really like this concept. Statistics often overwhelm people rather than inspiring them. The ability to connect with individual faces and hear their stories opens up some great possibilities.

Another great idea Nancy! Really gets potential donors to relate to potential recipients, as well as personalizes the scale of the issue. It'd be also great to build sharing mechanisms into the videos so that they can be virally spread (for example, recipients would forward to friends and families, who would then forward it out to their networks).

I like this concept. Especially if the video's can be hosted on YouTube and shared through social media as well, to increase the chance of making it viral, plus then it's not related to one country's registry. It relates a bit to my '_____ is a hero' concept.

rebrand_bone_marrow_donation_is_scary_le.description: I remember the first time someone asked me to be a bone marrow donor - I wanted to run away!  Once they explained the process I realized it's not scary at all.  To get more donors, we should change the name to Stem Cell Donation.
rebrand_bone_marrow_donation_is_scary_le.creator: f48860ccc50cf852e746f629f5bf22e4

comments.text: Stem cells sound less scary and more adaptable. Great idea.
I agree completely, bone marrow donation sounds much more serious than it is.
A great idea that addresses the emotional aspects of the reluctance of people to donate

Samantha, I love this idea! In my conversation with friends and research online, one of the most common misconception about bone marrow donation is it will be hurtful to body, it requires surgery, and it will be painful. A lot of graphic illustration made people have the impression that a lot of important part of your bone is being sucked out by poking your pelvic bone with a long needle. All these imageries increase discomfort and produce psychological resistance to donating. We can definitely do a better job designing a new brand / illustration to explain the process and impact in a joyful, engaging and moving way!
Absolutely Samantha! "Bone" and "Marrow" are both scary sounding, pain-inducing words.
Great idea.Sounds like a massive needle into my bone.

rebrand_bone_marrow_donation_is_scary_le.title: Rebrand!  Bone marrow donation is scary - let's have White Blood Cell Donation instead

dispelling_myths_about_marrow_donation.description: Building off of Ashley's inspiration ("But Does it Hurt"): it is crucial to dispel myths about bone marrow donation, and to revise the images that are conjured in people's minds whenever the words "Bone Marrow Donation" are mentioned
dispelling_myths_about_marrow_donation.creator: a46ad8b543de3b307685920dd10525e4

comments.text: It has been eye-opening to learn that 80% of donations can happen via a procedure similar to blood donations. However, the 1 in 5 chance that you could be asked to donate via surgical means may still give people pause and create a barrier to registering. According to the Be The Match FAQ, by signing up you agree to donate by either method. What if there was an option to register as a PBSC participant only, with the ability to "opt-in" if you were a match and the donation required a surgical procedure?

By just participating in this challenge and becoming more educated on this topic, I've learned that a lot of my assumptions about bone marrow donation have been completely false.  Knowing what I know now, I would be willing to register.  I wonder how many other participants are thinking the same thing now?

Thanks for sharing the useful links. I will take a closer look what is marrow donation really like.I totally agree with you that dispelling the myths is something essential to gain the deeper understanding and recognition of the issue.Including myself, people would probably have no idea about the disease and the donation procedure.If that is really as easy as blood donation and it won't cause pain then, making this as transparent as possible would be the key step.  We could probably take a look at existing blood donation campaign or strategy to get some inspiration.  While I was reading this I came up with an idea of campaign runed by insurance companies or hospitals.  What if you register as a donor of bone marrow  you will get some special condition on your insurance plan.  it could be discount, or it can be some kind of priority to get treated as a patient (maybe if you a donor you could get donated if in future this person gets some condition in need of transplant.

Re the 80% / 20% -since the call about which procedure to use is made by the recipient's physician, it means the potential donor needs to be prepared 100% to be asked to undergo surgery.  This is not a trivial decision to make.  I don't think a 1 in 5 chance that your donor experience will be much more involved than a blood draw qualifies this possibility as a myth.
So the question is how can some of the emotional barriers to approaching the unknown be overcome first, so people willbe open to the ration.

I think you hit the nail on the head by pointing out the percentages, that is key. When I organized a drive at my company, the woman from the Asian American Donor Program that I coordinated with gave us each a laminated sheet that we could show to people when we approached them. On the sheet was some general info, and then two images side-by-side of the different procedures with two sentence descriptions, and a 75% above the outpatient procedure and 25% above the surgical procedure. I thought it was very effective and it made it much easier for us to explain things to potential registrants!

I had a bone marrow transplant.  While it was for breast cancer, which they don't do anymore, I had no idea what was expected of me or the people I might need to help me.  Transplants are not an everyday procedure, or something most people think about until needed.It's mysterious to the patient and the donor.  It's a difficult and very hard treatment.  Whenever I'm asked about it, I have to explain it.  I'm sure it's the same for donor's.As a patient, I had to learn about donors and their role, before I could ask anyone to help me.I was able to be my own marrow donor, however, I still needed peripheral stem cells.  Patients are a resource and might be willing to be used in an education campaign, along with previous donor's.
Key: pointing out that 80% of all donations involve a procedure similar to donating blood (rather than the more invasive process people typically associate with being a bone marrow donor)

Hello Vineet, I think you have a very important point here.Until some hours ago I wasn't familiar with the procedure for bone marrow donation at all and I'd have been concerned about the "But Does it Hurt" factor.Ashley mentions that some times the procedure has side effects lasting even some weeks. I think this most be mentioned upfront to donors (avoiding panicking them) so they could know what to expect.

dispelling_myths_about_marrow_donation.title: Dispelling Myths About Marrow Donation

start_with_the_kids.description: Launching an education campaign in schools focusing the kids may be a good way of discussing the bone marrow donation process with transparency, to get the right information to the parents and prevent some barriers to appear.
start_with_the_kids.creator: fb7c07a25a919927c292cb2f91cfccc9

comments.text: HANDWOVEN EARLY AWARENESS WRIST BANDS BY SCHOOL CHILDREN: We also think it is a great idea to involve school children in building awareness about the need to increase the bone marrow donor registry.  When you join the bone marrow/stem cell donor registry at one Genny's Hope Foundation donor drives, we say thank you by providing you a handmade "early awareness" bracelet made by local school children. Involving school children in weaving these bracelets increases understanding for the need of donors. After all, today's school children are tomorrow's stem cell donors. The children are taught that the bracelets are woven in three primary colors which have representative meaning:  red (red blood cells and platelets), white (white blood cells), and cream (bone marrow).  Each bracelet has a tiny orange bead to represent Leukemia.  We provide the weaving kits to the schools.  We have grade school students who weave using yarn and junior high and high school students who weave using embroidery thread.  We primarily concentrate our drives at universities and colleges and the students who enroll on the registry have really enjoyed these bracelets.  They wear them proudly.  Visit us at http://www.facebook.com/GennysHopeFoundation on Facebook or at www.gennyhope.org

Starting with children is always a good idea as they are curious, eager to learn and can be influential catalysts for change. However, I believe the kids represented in the photo are too young to wrap their heads around a complex concept such as bone marrow. Sure, the content could be taught on a very basic level but this might prevent the children from understanding the true value of marrow transplants. Also, it may instill a certain amount of fear in them (I know when I was little, I'd hear about diseases and be sure I had them or that I'd get them soon)...I'd recommend starting at an 8th grade level or higher and embedding the conversation into a science curriculum. It would be great to solicit insights and/or anecdotes from students whose families have been personally touched by cancer. This provides a human element and a basis for greater motivation to act. Classrooms could definitely partner with sick kids or adults (those requiring bone marrow transplants) and with today's technology, there could be constant communication between students and patients via live video streaming, emails and photos. This pen-pal relationship would be mutually beneficial as it would provide added support and an outlet for patients (some who might not have a built in support network) and an educational opportunity for students.

What I like in the idea is that it is a way to reach both children and parents. I've seen this in a project we did on climate change with first graders in my kids' school: the kids taught their parents and make them aware, and they also forced them to change their behaviors. So we might not know if these children will remember to donate when they are 18, but their parents might donate.

Hi Fernanda.  Interesting idea.  Starting children early learning about how they can help others whether it be donating blood, organs, or marrow I think is a great way to build awareness and start the conversation.  Do you think there's a way we could continue to instill these values as these children grow older?  As children we all had the "DARE" program in elementary school and learned to not take drugs, but as we all grew into adults, I we really remembered was that drugs were bad, but not the details.  I wonder if when these kids are legal age, if they'll remember to sign up.

Really nice concept Fernanda, and great builds Karen and Justin! I especially like the idea of kids writing letters about donation to themselves to open at 18, or to other neighborhood teenagers who are old enough to donate. Kids teaching kids!

What a lovely idea, Fernanda,  After all, education is everything, and I am thinking  some form of toys could be introduced to make learning more playable for kids. Please view the link below as a reference http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1120666/Gutted-Company-recalls-cuddly-uterus-toy-OVARIES-attached-choking-hazard.html

I like your idea of addressing the fears/misunderstanding about donation at a young age. It'd also be helpful to add an activity for the kids to "pledge" to register when they are old enough as a reminder. Perhaps they could write themselves a letter (or email) that gets sent on their birthday as a reminder to get registered when they turn 18 (or whatever the age requirement is for that country). Or -- since kids writing letters is just so cute -- have them make birthday card reminders to the teenagers turning 18 in their neighborhood each year :)

Awesome idea Sarah! Though I may be biased, since I started checking out multi-user virtual worlds back when text-based MUDS were state of the art, and wrote a college admissions essay about applying these to education.Could definitely see this integrated into a gaming world where the recipient's health is immediately improved while the donor's movement speed is slowed down for a short time, which they quickly recover from. Maybe even some change in alignment or hero stat bonus.

dude. you get points simply for including WoW in the mix. Just tell players that they're accounts will be shutdown if they don't register, and they will all donate immediately! On a serious note, as I mentioned in my eval of this, virtual communities like WoW and SL have strong social networking leverage.
Hi Bo - definitely - thanks for the connection!

Great idea, reminds me of Jane McConigal -- she's a game designer/game researcher who advocates the idea of using game for social good http://www.ted.com/talks/jane_mcgonigal_gaming_can_make_a_better_world.html  Hope Lab has also developed games to promote health behavior among young people http://www.hopelab.org/innovative-solutions/.

How about extending it into some of the popular Facebook games like Farmville or there's some game about Mafia? Not my area of expertise I'm afraid either but I heard some pretty impressive statistics amount the number of people playing these sorts of games on a regular basis.The ones connected to social media could have an added awareness spreading bonus because peole see status updates from them even if they don't play themselves. Really interesting worlds to explore, nice work spotting the opportunity!

Hi Krassimira, according to crunchbase -http://www.crunchbase.com/company/secondlife - one million active residents in August 2008. I haven't heard much news about it lately - it may be on the out - which is what made me think of more current things like World of Warcraft - although harder to bring in the social aspect - may work if the game makers would be up for it. Maybe you could do something more subtle like organ donation card for your avatar in case you die?! I guess they probably don't have hospitals and ERs in there - I've never played - definitely need some feedback on this one.
Sarah, I think this is a great idea! I was just wondering how popular is Second Life these days? Do you know? And also do we know who is target audience?

virtual_bone_marrow_registration.title: Virtual Bone Marrow Registration

py/tuple: How easy is this concept to implement?
I could start right now.
This might take a bit of planning and probably some help from several partners.
This is a big undertaking and I'd need a lot of help from friends, organizations and other groups to make it happen.
Will this concept successfully reach and encourage under-represented populations (including South Asians) to join the bone marrow registry?
Yes, this concept will resonate with diverse groups of people from all over the world.
No, this concept might not reach under-represented populations very well.
I'm not sure, but I hope so!
How well does this concept dispel myths, ease fears, or provide education about bone marrow registration and donation?
Really well -- I already feel like I have a better understanding of the process and why it's important.
Okay, though it'll still take some explaining to get people to understand how bone marrow registration and donation work.
Not very well -- we'd have to create a highly detailed plan around this concept to help people understand.
How scalable is this concept?
This concept is highly scalable and could easily impact people all over the world.
This concept is really best suited for small groups and local areas.
This concept could be scaled, but we'd have to refine it for different settings.

the_cultural_barriers_to_donation_.description: Socio-Cultural barriers exist in many parts of the world, particularly in less education, rural areas. Many studies have been done that reveal the underlying fears and misconceptions.

comments.text: Fabulous and so very relevant, Nathan! Good find. I'm most curious about this aspect of this particular challenge. Especially as someone who fears needles and blood herself!

the_cultural_barriers_to_donation_.title: The Cultural Barriers to Donation

_university_based_open_innovation_awaren.description: University-based crowdsourcing competition challenge platform to encourage ways of promoting registry increase (a website with DIY resources, open source challenge platform, materials, promo stuff, etc.). It's hard not to get involved when you're coming up with ideas to get others involved!
_university_based_open_innovation_awaren.creator: 3477f2719c2ec13566dddb41787b8089

comments.text: Jennifer and I will be mentioning your concept as well as all the winning ideas at the Stanford conference this Saturday. Congratulations again.
wow thanks nathan. very humbled and incredibly fulfilling to be part of this community of do-gooders.
how did it go chief?
Sina did you know your idea was the main inspiration for the drive in a box idea that helped 100k cheeks reach and surpass their goal of 100,000 cheeks?
Congrats, Sina!
thx krassimira

Sina - great ideas!  Another avenue that aligns with your insights is a business school case competition ... a forum for collaboration, healthy competition, and awareness promotion.  For inspiration, check out Hult's recent challenge to provide clean water solutions around the world: http://hultglobalcasechallenge.com/.   You could extend a concept like Hult, which includes business schools across the world, by creating an online forum for all participants.

Brilliant, Sina! As I said in the evaluation form, it makes me want to go to the university close by and talk them into doing a competition with their students. I will be teaching there later this year, so who knows :).Sorry I had missed this one earlier, but I guess I was too caught up in the food challenge. Anyway: *applause*!

What a great idea! You really captured 'my feelings'! By engaging in a challenge, everyone gets more aware of the problem and goes deeper in the subject. By doing that we address other barriers like misunderstanding and feeling rushed.Building on this, these challenges and engagements could go beyond an online platform, and be followed by events or workshops within the community. It would feel more personal and would be a powerful experience for the community.

I really like the suggestion that there be a chat feature that allows you to immediately connect to someone who can tell you where to register or other information. That would be a useful thing to add to any program for this challenge.

_university_based_open_innovation_awaren.title: University-Based Open Innovation Awareness Websites built on a DIY Kit

comments.text: You make a good point on defining the touch points of the system but I think the action should be focussed on how to engage people deeply. Getting the attention and enabling them to take action is kinda solved. The example I can give is that a simple advert, depending on the media, can reach millions and the action (swab/register) is already pretty straight forward procedure (as seen here http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-number-of-bone-marrow-donors-to-help-save-more-lives/inspiration/swabbing-my-cheek/).Thus we gotta wonder. What gets people engaged?

interactive_map_registered_donors.description:
Inspired by a diabetes map of the US which reveals health, income and socio-economic divides and by Haiyan, who created a map to show the radiation levels in different cities in Japan, http://japan.failedrobot.com/,  I thought we can create a map of all bone marrow registered donors and build a community around the map. This concept merges with Arjan's concept BeTheInternationalMatch.org and is adjusted to reflect the combination of both concepts in one. 
Goal: have one single point of information- globally centralized interactive map for donor centers, national registries, donor drives and other information on a central site.
interactive_map_registered_donors.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: Nice! Thanks, Krassimira. If it is difficult with the picture, just be sure to copy the link. It is a GoogleMap with open collaboration, so you can even add information near you :)
Arjan, I think this will absolutely work and I think this is a great approach; so, I'm copying the text of your concept in my concept and I will try to add the googe maps picture

Great, Krassimira. Now to find a way to integrate them all. Do you think you could incorporate the text of mine here, then I will put in the comments of mine, and in the text, that the concepts are combined and that for further feedback, we should use this one. Do you think that would work?

Arjan, I do agree with you that combining the three concepts will make a very strong one which will be interactive, engaging and motivating, too. And as Camilla mentioned in the comment below, it is quite important to make it intriguing....
Camilla, thanks for your feedback!

I really like your idea! Your idea is one of the first concepts I've read that I find fun, if I can use that word in this context. I get intrigued about the information7visualisation and want to learn mroe! I think one of the biggest problem with getting people to be involved in different projects/help aid/donations is that they feel bothered and have decided even before they've read the information, that they are not interesting. This mapping also makes it more logical to follow one otherwise quite emotional project. To have a project that have both parts i think will mean that it will reach out to even more people -> a better concept.
Arjan, great idea! A person who is logged on to the interactive map can send invites to his/her facebook friends...

Oh, and in the comments of my concept, Justin proposed to combine that one with the Know Your Type concept of Brett - http://3bl.me/qcqe5m . I think if we combine all three, it would be a strong concept. What do you think?
Nice idea. From this starting point, registered donors can also invite others. Much more interactive and dynamic than my concept which you related to this one. Super!

interactive_map_registered_donors.title: Interactive map of registered donors

inspirational_and_informative_emotions_c.description: Use inspirational videos that tell a story that solicits emotional response and commitment, while providing practical steps to take action (i.e. register/donate). This would include producing different types of videos for various audience segments. What would remain universal in all videos is the power of the story. Story telling is more than information sharing it is the art of triggering imagination to arouse empathy--and we are, after all, we are empathetic creatures and make most of our decisions on emotion (not reason). These videos would be short segments that could be shared on TV but primarily on the web.
inspirational_and_informative_emotions_c.creator: 3477f2719c2ec13566dddb41787b8089

comments.text: Krassimira I absolutely agree. If you could get small videos like this in clinics and public spots (but notably where men gather) it would increase awareness of importance of material health > could also be used to get people to use mobile phones and tell the story of how it could help O.-

Sina, when I watched the video, which tells a story in a brilliant way, I immediately thought it applies to our maternal challenge. Kirk had an idea along the same line- check these two concepts- http://bit.ly/dIqWbp and http://bit.ly/dNRsYx.

inspirational_and_informative_emotions_c.title: inspirational and informative: emotions count

That's hilarious! Great move on Dogfish's part =)

saving_a_life_priceless_.description: One 2-minute cheek swab. Five shots over five days. The life of a two-year-old boy: priceless. Join 100K Cheeks, and register to donate bone marrow.
saving_a_life_priceless_.creator: 8ce17b76f2e475e02b7fa08bf7a92b1b

comments.text: Great campaign ideas Laura and Seisho! Simple, touching, and to the point.

This priceless campaign is a great inspiration,  it could illustrate the message such simple way with strong impact. When I saw the image of the campaign the HSBC ad they did in the airport to illustrate the cultural difference for some reason.  It could have a sets of paired image that illustrate giving side and receiving side (not necessary sell&buy situation) with one word copy that explain some detail(it could be price, it could be time, name of thing that was given, and name of thing that was gained and etc).  For example you have an image of someone giving a lift to work or school (for giving side "5 mins" for receiving side "30mins" then in the end of series you could have donator with "20 mins" and patient with "lifetime".Please feel free to build on this!

saving_a_life_priceless_.title: Saving a Life: Priceless

a_sponsored_pick_the_winner_be_the_winne.description: If you are the match you win a prize, if you find the match you also win a prize. Making both equally rewarding encourages people to participate and motivates them to spread the word at the same time.
a_sponsored_pick_the_winner_be_the_winne.creator: a32d7735d79dc9ba49691cd336e3c51b

comments.text: Hi Ben!You may think it's shallow but everyone likes a reward and we know that rewards motivate people to make decisions!  Getting brands on board (sustainable ones would be especially good) to support the awards could be beneficial.If companies come on board, cost wouldn't be an issue!

a_sponsored_pick_the_winner_be_the_winne.title: A sponsored Pick the Winner Be the Winner

how_could_we_provide_equal_value_to_the_.description: People feel content if they receive as much value as they give out for something.Therefore the values must be equal on both sides. make_it_count_competition.description: Create a network of local competitions, organized nationally, to register the most marrow donors, and announce local winners at the same time all over the country on local TV stations, perhaps after an event like the Superbowl, which draws huge numbers of viewers. The winners become local celebrities, and each group has a huge incentive to register more people!

do_good_deeds_for_seeds.description: As a reward for their donation the participants could be give seeds in plant in a shared community garden. These local gardens could be connected globally through a shared website and google maps. As the garden grows it a) creates a shared community space to bring people together and b) it provides a visual snapshot of all donations.
do_good_deeds_for_seeds.creator: c6d2ed9ca2d2c2e31841e6501f8eddf9

comments.text: I like this, and would build on it.  The seeds are a great metaphor -your donation implies a lifelong commitment to the matching process, and you;re giving life in the forms of seeds.  Could these seeds be for robust new trees? Something that grows not just for a season but for about the length of a human life?
very poetic :)
Loving the idea that as it grows, the garden represents a "visual snapshot" of everyone who's donated. Nice work Jen!

do_good_deeds_for_seeds.title: Do Good Deeds for Seeds

corporate_social_responsibility_bone_mar.description: Make bone marrow donation awareness drive a mandatory CSR activity.

The winning corporation gets some free donated advertising from a media partner(s).
_saved_lives_this_year_and_counting..._.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: Sarah, thanks for the comment, I really beleivesuch a sign can become very engaging!

Krassimira, this is totally random, but I used to work at Martin-Baker, who make ejection seats! As you drove through the gates every day there was a big sign saying the number of lives saved to date. It was a great reminder of purpose and drive. I think this is a really nice and simple idea.
Arjan, Vincent and Chloe, thanks for the comments! And I totally agree that this is a nice add-on to Chloe's concept to increase awareness and encourage employees to sign up.

Vincent, nice way to connect the two. This is a perfect way to a) encourage more employee to sign up; b) increase awareness of importance of bone marrow donation in the public; c) bring positive press coverage for the companies. There are companies setting up huge display of carbon counter in public space to raise awareness on climate change. A "life saved counter" through bone marrow donation will definitely flies!
This would be a good component for Chloe's company partnership concept: http://bit.ly/fU5cyM

This is a very interesting concept. It plays well on the competitive nature of large corporations, especially with their competition. The first organisations to target for this could be the ones that are already corporate sponsors for donor-related charities. They already have a connection. I remember that when I tried to organise a run challenge for the big corporation I was part of, it really connected with people because they already knew the charity because we were deeply involved with them as a corporate sponsor.

comments.text: Thanks for your comments, Lin and Larry. @ Lin, the concept here is to 'lure' people into registering for cheek swab/blood test with an incentive of 'in kind' and 'in cash' returns. However, I do agree that this would probably work much better for monetary donations.

Anuja...i think this concept is excellent for promoting money donations...but not necessary make direct impact on increasing the marrow donor registrations which involves cheek swab/blood test to put their DNA info into the system.

Although I have to admit I dont understand the mechanics of the idea, I really like that its showing me a different way of thinking about the mechanisms involved and how they might interact differently.
Thank you Alexis and Ashley. I am glad the idea is appreciated :)
This is a really good idea, and would provide a very strong incentive for people to become donors. This is especially true among increasing health costs, where this kind of insurance is invaluable.

Congrats Anuja on such a great concept, and a wonderful video illustrating your idea! I really like the idea of switching our thinking from "donating" to "investing" - and your model shows us how an actual investment could work. Nice job!

Agreed. Amazing!
You don't want to break the bone chain!
Felix, this is such a cool idea. Definitely post it up again for the Concepting stage that starts in a few days!

opt_out_when_you_are_tested.description: People that are donating blood, or are preparing for non-lifethreatening injuries or treatments are often having their blood or other health indicators tested. Why not make not becoming a bone marrow donor an opt out in that process.
opt_out_when_you_are_tested.creator: 6fed0e6f1ba44f0520bc14fceee3663d

comments.text: Hey Paul! Saw the video you starred in for the OPI / Greenbook. Really cool. Did it air on National Geographic?Thanks for the comment. I think you're right, it's really important to have a personal touch at the moment the donor gets asked to overcome any fears, barriers and answer questions.

That's an interesting strategy to get them opt out if they really dont want. Getting more people in the database is crucial. Then, if they are ever called, the procedure can be re-explained, a doctor deal with the donor's fear on a one to one basis. They still can opt out at that time, but I am sure many would accpet!!

opt_out_when_you_are_tested.title: Opt Out When You Are Tested

free_health_coverage_for_donor_registrat.description: Industry sponsored health coverage in exchange for registry.
free_health_coverage_for_donor_registrat.creator: 37bf36ced68099da3b607c9a07a88ac1

comments.text: Good thoughts.Be the Match however does not like registering people if they have not guaranteed they will donate.  It costs $60-80 to type a kit, and currently only 50% of registrants actually continue to the donation stage if matched.  This is a big problem and wastes a lot of money.

Creative thinking Tony! I previously made a comment on a William's regulated organ sales inspiration (http://bit.ly/enI0j3), which supports your inspiration. So just re-pasting it below: "Very true that financial incentives could significantly affect behavior, though the ethical implications are huge. One potential form of compensation would be a complimentary period of healthcare coverage for the donor. This would provide a clear additional benefit for the donor, as well as reassurance that they would be taken care of if there were complications from the donation. It's non-transferability would address some black market concerns. And it may make economic sense for stakeholders like health insurers, as the costs of treating a patient who doesn't receive a donation are often even higher."I also wonder what's the current stance of government regulations is on this kind of a program.

free_health_coverage_for_donor_registrat.title: Free Health Coverage for Donor Registration

Hy theresuperb idea but wouldn't it be more efficient to go:1)Awareness2)Spread the word3)Registration4)Donationto get even more people involved?Just a thought
Indeed! It starts tomorrow. Can't wait to see what you come up with!
