comments.text: Awesome idea -- I am sure it would get people to donate, and participation would greatly enhance a company's image.

Interesting idea : partner with companies and win-win partnership.But i'm not sure that time is the main problem : you can be a donator and never donate simply because you don't match with the donation needs (the time between the donation and the transplant can't exceed 24 hours, so you can't store marrow samples as you can with blood sample).Is reward also a major issue ?France is the eight donator country, with less than 200 000 donators, and any kind reward for bone marrow is illegal for ethics purposes. If i'm not wrong USA is first donator (6 millions) and Germany second (4 millions). Is bone marrow reward in USA and Germany authorised ? I'm not sure that reward is key for explaining such differences in number of donators.Bone marrow sample does'nt systematically cure : in many cases it increases life expectancy about 2 or 3 years (with 50% of death). Sure, it depends of the kind of disease, but bone marrow samples are often used to increase life expectancy of people submited to heavy chemotherapy and or radiotherapy.So, on an strict health insurance costs increasing bone marrow donation increases life expectancy to chemotherapy and or radiotherapy, so increases chemotherapy and radiotherapy costs.So i fear that  health insurance costs might not be a good key.Perhaps a more humanitarian focus should be adopted ? A win-win partnership focused on indirect benefits, like strenghtened motivation inside corporations, stronger corporation spirit ?

Thanks everyone for your encouraging comments! I really appreciate it. :) In response to the comments, I have added in a simple diagram to illustrate the respective benefits for corporation, employees, and bone marrow donation agencies. Susan, I think it's a fantastic idea to add in the extra incentives for companies from health insurance cost perspectives. This would be the ideal situation if we can also get the insurance companies on board.  It requires strong alliances between bone marrow donation agencies and networks of private corporations to create big enough influence to push for the change from health insurance industry. It's definitely worth pursuing. With the current concept, the company benefits from positive corporate images, and most likely better employee engagement, because employee would think their company cares. Taylor, I am glad you love this idea! :) I envision once there are significant amount of employees signed up in each company, mentoring / buddies network can be initiated within or even across industries to share stories, build knowledge and fostering friendships. I will not be surprised that individual may be able to find donor match if they or their family members are in need of help.
Really interesting and well-designed concept Chloe! And kudos to all the folks who've left such supportive and encouraging comments.

This concept appears to be very well thought out - I love the details provided for how a program could be implemted through the private sector. Many companies are now engaging in biometric testing for their employees as a part of the overall health and wellness program. Perhaps linking with these already establish programs would help reduce overall costs incurred. The medical professional is already there for testing so could take swabs as well. Employees are educated through monthly wellness newsletters and have plenty of time to ask questions. I think a danger to the "quick and dirty" donor drives is that people get caught up in peer pressure to join but then may opt out of donating due to lack of information. This concept avoids that. (Sorry to be long winded! Clearly I love this idea.)

Chloe, I think you've done a great job in working through the life cycle of why people would be motivated to donate, it's a really well thought through concept. Would there also be a way to reward the company for taking part? I know a lot of big companies supply health insurance free to staff, could they get some kind of reduced cost from the insurance companies? Surely, the health costs involved in treating a patient will be reduced the more people are willing to be a registered doner so it's a win win situation for both the employer and insurance company. Well done on a great concept!
Agreed with Dara & Krassimira, you really did an excellent job in envisioning a program that's both attractive to people and larger companies!
Even in Germany where we have 30 vacation days per year, additional days are still quite an incentive! Great job structuring your concept, Chloe!
This would definitely motivate me to donate, especially in North America where we get so few vacation days.  Great idea partnering with the private sector!

cost_no_more.description: Some great concepts addressing the barrier of cost got me thinking - can we eliminate cost as a barrier altogether?
cost_no_more.creator: 821303cd32910cb57445342073cfe1a6

comments.text: Hi Susan,Thanks for building on this - these are great ideas! It takes coordination, but I think small interventions would definitely add up. Chatting with organizations involved to map out their supply chain and quantify costs at each step could also inform which areas to tackle.

Hi Brinda,I really like how your concept is addressing the issue of cost as a barrier. Especially I think that your second stage of simplifying the supply chain is good because it has room to grow as an idea. As well as creating centralized back offices, which seems like one of those ideas which is so simple it's brilliant, I wondered how could you cost save on other aspects? Is it possible there could be a series of small interventions that would cut costs, I'm imagining things like* asking people when posting back their completed swab test to include all original packaging so it can be reused* when someone orders a test kit prompting them if they could send a second kit to have a friend complete it (no need to post twice)* using freely available software such google apps to process the data* getting access to commercial/college labs to do tests at weekends for freeJust a few extra thoughts that could combine to make the concept even stronger, well done on tackling a really hard aspect of the challenge!

cost_no_more.title: Cost no more

a_trolley_with_a_story.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: Starting conversations - excellent!

Thanks for sharing this, Jane! I see the power of catching attention and starting conversations with friends, families, even with people you randomly meet. My idea with the trolley with the story goes exactly along these lines.

What a fun way to attract attention and curiosity to seed awareness! It makes me think of the campaign that DonorsChoose.org did to create awareness and raise money for their public school project funding marketplace. Individuals grew mustaches in a campaign called "Mustache for Kids". They had to grow the mustache (only a mustache a la Magnum PI, no goatee or beard to disguise the mustache) from scratch and were not allowed to shave until a certain time and reach a pledge amount. The fact that you had this silly caterpillar on your face all of a sudden called attention and acted as a conversation starter with friends, family, etc. My husband participated in this and some people even pledged double so he would shave off his mustache, myself included. Now granted, this campaign wouldn't have the same impact in say Mexico or India where mustaches are more entrenched...but a similar idea could be applied to another part of your face. The important difference is that the mustache or whatever is always with you. How could we bring that ever-present aspect to the trolley or any other kind of conversation starter?
Kris, I really like this!

Krassimira. Thank you for reaching out. I like your idea a lot and think Nancy's comment below, re tote bags, is a good extension of your idea. I think it would be interesting to apply Nancy's idea to trolleys. Each time someone travels to do pro-social work that person is awarded a sticker that is placed on the trolley similarly to the way a stamp is placed in the passport.

Sydney, thanks for the comment and sharing the link. I do believe that starting a conversation in a more casual way has a moment of surprise and this makes an idea stick. I belive this is very powerful.

This idea reminds me a lot of the concept used by Falling Whistles (http://www.fallingwhistles.com/) where they have a simple, eye-catching icon that starts conversation about the terrible war and human rights violations going on in the Congo. Their whole concept is about starting active conversation and involvement through casual mediums, and about inspiring others in a topic they normally wouldn't have been interested in simply through a human conversation. The awareness part is extremely important and I like the concept this idea touches on.

This is interesting and I like how it plays on the "gotta collect them all" ideas like FourSquare badges.  I feel like these days, it's kind of hip to have a canvas tote that tells people to recycle etc.  If there was a canvas tote that you could collect patches for based on the causes you helped & places you've donated to, it would be kind of cool.  In this case, maybe when you give blood you get a cool new iron on patch & when you signup for the bone marrow registry you get another?  Fun idea.
I like this idea, as engaging in a conversation and attracting peoples' attention  has a lot of potential....

a_trolley_with_a_story.title: A Trolley with a Story

from_children_2019_s_green_food_producti.creator: 0275289955d358e131296157000ab211

comments.text: I worked in several community organizing projects in Bangladesh, Lesotho, Namibia and Pakistan where I organized community adult education, community children education, community irrigation, and community farming. I found these projects promoted not only adult education, child education, but also facilitated networking and solidarity among them.
Livestock development program could be included too.

Homestead gardening, backyard poultry, community gardening and community kitchen food preparation ideas could be promoted through social businesses. The group-based micro-credit scheme for these entrepreneurs could help the development of the local green entrepreneurship in the community. Through this initiative, agricultural education, nutrition education, human- centered public health education and gender development could be promoted too.

Elementary school teachers could develop a demonstration plot for the students for vegetable production, timber nursaries and vegetable seed production, so that they can grow vegetables, nursaries and seeds outside the school premises in the neighborhoods. Teachers could teach students how to use the seeds and preserve the seeds. Moreover, the teachers could visit childrens homestead home gardening plots, compost plots, seed production plots, and nurseries.Teachers should describe for students the benefits of organic compost and the use of integrated pest management instead of chemical fertilizers and pesticides. Moreover, green non-governmental organizations or green energy extension workers could be invited demonstrate the biogas plants, energy savings stoves and solar energy installation in the community. Form a childrens food growing, food marketing and consuming cooperative and link this cooperative with the farmers cooperatives, food marketing and food selling cooperative in the community.The teachers could advise the children to grow vegetables and prepare pizza or other types of food at home from their produced vegetables, poultry, and then bring the food to the school for some occasion (a potluck or food fair). This local fresh organic food produce would add additional vitamins, minerals and enzymes into the diet. There could also be encouragement provided to local community members to make ceramic plates and baskets with the local soil/mud, local plants and link these products to the local market and motivate the people to use them.Advise students and parents about the affects of chemical fertilizers, pesticides; danger of fast food/canned food and Trans fats for health in the student and parents gathering sessions. Save rain fall water and use it for irrigation. Food waste can be put in the compost hole. Include community gardens, seed production and preservation and nutritional education as part of the school curriculum. There could be a curriculum from Grade 2-Grade 5 for homestead gardening, backyard poultry farming, benefits of compost and organic food, pesticide-free foods and sundried storage food. Develop some educational flip charts, popular songs, and theater about the effects of fast food and advice about the benefits of a balanced diet and optimum organic fresh food intake. Excess food intake, carbohydrates, sugar, saturated fats are harmful to health and cause obesity, diabetes, and heart disease. This information could be shared with parents in the parents gathering sessions. Students can debate about how to produce food and preserve seeds. There could be an annual competition among the community children for drawing posters/pictures regarding community food production and food consumption.Organize an annual gathering for community food security; lean season food production and marketing. Food producers, food sellers and consumers could all be present in this annual gathering. This could be a tool to organize the community farmers and link them to the food producers, sellers and consumers. Farmers, sellers and consumers could be gathered together where farmers can show their products, meet with buyers and consumers and exchange ideas among them. This gathering could help producers directly know what buyers and consumers prefer.  Create networking among parents/farmers, sellers and consumers. Create more advertising on community farmers products on community radio, T.V., community newspapers etc. Promote vegetable and fruit growing and selling businesses, seed growing and selling businesses, nurseries and green food businesses in the community in a cooperative way by providing micro-credit loans to these organic fertilizer entrepreneurs, organic vegetable growers, seed growers, seed sellers, nursery planters and green food sellers for their green business capital. The microcredit loans could help social businesses entrepreneurs to sell their green products with cheap prices, which could be affordable to the local people and revitalize the community social economy. Moreover, organize annual green food festival fairs with fresh vegetable stalls and organic food stalls. The micro-credit program could help the community green food micro entrepreneurs to develop their business in their local community.  All classes of people irrespective of gender, generation, culture and religion should be involved in this food production and consumption education, local green food businesses. I can design a micro credit project for promoting the local food production and food selling businesses.  The idea of using organic fertilizer production leading to organic food production and then balanced diets rich in locally grown foods could be replicated in other elementary schools and adult learning schools. This could be a green business model for students, parents and teachers in the community. The whole food chain of green food production to green food consumption to green business could bring children, youth, and farmers attention to local food sharing, intergenerational food sharing, local agricultural production and marketing knowledge, interchanging cooperative, collective  and innovative community social business learning, social business transformative learning, informal learning, lifelong learning, incidental learning, reusing and recycling of the organic food wastage  for sustainable individual self-care, family network nutrition services and community-driven economic development in the society. It could promote local mutual support, learning-by-doing, good health of individuals and the human-centered well-being of families and communities, and local living social economy as well as self-employment through local food growing, and local food selling.

The concept "From childrens green food production to green food consumption to green business model"could revitalize students connection with the local green food production, community network through food production, food share;  and promote organic food production, community social businesses  and local living economics.

from_children_2019_s_green_food_producti.title: From children’s green food production to green food consumption to green business model

thanks, ashley :)

I think this draws really nicely on how people are more likely to be convinced when they've got a person to connnect them to the 'ask'. I'm not sure it's relevant but I was thinking about added incentives that would convince people to go along and sign up. Since the health care professional is already there, could each member of the party be allowed a time to ask them questions about other issues too? I know its really expensive to see a Doctor where I live, so perhaps, if people could avoid this cost in exchange for going to a party and being open to the idea of registering as a bone marrow donor they'd be easier convinced. Though I think even without any added incentive it's a great concept and really addressed barriers in a thoughtful and very people centred way. Well Done!

Thanks for the inspiring comments!!Louise, this homepage you posted the link for is really interesting, thank you! I also think the trick with getting people together for a common interest works really well.And Katie, thanks for pointing out the one-on-one situation. That is really the main aspect that striked me when thinking about the Tupperware system. To meet an expert in a familiar environment and being able to ask maybe personal questions seems an important issue to me that have not been adressed too much yet. And I think getting the invitation from a friend or at least someone you know will convince people easier to just give it a chance and join in for the evening! The threshold of actually relating the issue of bone marrow donation to oneself as a potential donor seems much lower to me.
Fantastic idea (and that picture is hilarious by the way). I love that you could have a one-on-one with an expert too.
nice idea, Veronica. Reminds me of the Swishing, swap shop clothes events that are run.  Have a look at www.swishing.co.uk - works well for getting woman together in a common interest

comments.text: Very true that financial incentives could significantly affect behavior, though the ethical implications are huge. One potential form of compensation would be a complimentary period of healthcare coverage for the donor. This would provide a clear additional benefit for the donor, as well as reassurance that they would be taken care of if there were complications from the donation. It's non-transferability would address some black market concerns. And it may make economic sense for stakeholders like health insurers, as the costs of treating a patient who doesn't receive a donation are often even higher.

comments.text: Brinda  I really liked this article when it came out> http://www.ssireview.org/articles/entry/the_dragonfly_effect/. Picking up on your comment, I wonder if we could fit (without too much brute force!) this idea into the Drangonfly framework?Focus: We need a measureable goal. I think we could get there with number of lives saved? In a single prison, how many people have a second chance at life because of the actions of this prison community And I cant help but think this goal fits perfectly with incarceration? Just a gut feelingGrab Attention: Unfortunately, I dont see a way through this without rewards? Is it a stipend in your prisoner account if you do donate? Is it more time outside? Moving to a different prison block? Better job? Prisoners will want to see whats in it for them at this stage.Engage: It takes one life (perhaps in any prison) to show the significance of donating marrow. Picture of prisoner to left, picture of person saved to the right. Would that person be willing to come to the prison and thank the prisoners? Attach a face to the act of kindness. I think there are a lot of options around engagement.Take Action: Here, I think we use an old idea. Print/publicize the names of those who did register. I want my name up there I want to others to see my name. But, basically randomization (experiments) would be needed here. Publicity? Competition with other prison? Helping someone in local community? Focusing efforts on children alone?Ill close by saying I see a raging debate right now on prisoner organ donation all over the net. Organs after lethal injection? Cost to harvest organs? Lots of issues. Blood drives are also an issue (tattoos, etc.).  I wonder if bone marrow flies under the radar  no infection, healthy, 18-60? Minorities are overrepresented in prisons and underrepresented in registries.
Important Edit to the comment below: Aaker's book is "The Dragonfly Effect" - I need to be more careful with spelling/citations!

David & Sally,The links below might help your research. There is a lot of evidence that giving makes givers feel good. This applies to everyone, not just prisoners of course, but David's point that you have a captive audience at a prison + Sally's point that you have a "ripe" audience (individuals who might feel an above average need to redeem themselves) are powerful ones and make prisons a pretty attractive target for social deeds. The first link is some research conducted by Jennifer Aaker, a professor at Stanford and co-author of "The Dragonfly Affect." A snippet from her research: The easiest way to catch happinessand spread itis by doing good." http://www.smmmagazine.com/magazine/issue01/feature-academic.htmlThis second link is an NPR story on the affect of teaching Vipassana mediation in prison facilities. The medidation forces reflection, and one of its special "side effects" is that it engenders a desire to give back. The studies on Vipassana in prison settings suggest that there is a real desire for members of these prison communities to do good...to feel good. http://www.npr.org/2011/02/08/133505880/at-end-of-the-line-prison-an-unlikely-escapeThanks for your posts!

Sally - I can maybe do some research around this, but my initial thought is to remove containment from the equation. We are all exploited in small ways -- just look at work! But we have freedom to leave our company. Stop them from taking advantage. Then there are those who cannot escape. Prisoners are an example of this... But within that containment, there are choices. Do I try to be a model prisoner? Do I establish my presence? Do I jockey for the best job? Do I read books that better me? I think the registry is one more option. We make you go to prison. We make you live in a tiny cell. We restrict your time outside. But we don't force you to join the registry.But are we hitting on something here? Is it easier to boil cold water? You have committed a horrific crime. You can save an 8 year olds life. Do those extremes work to the benefit of a registry? Who knows... My guess is that a registry would fit within the intra-dynamics of a prison and not within the prison system as a whole.PS: Wonder if we give prisoners better conditions all the time? They may trade it like currency? Maybe redemption isn't front and center with this idea... Not sure??

Hey David, I'm really attracted to the idea of redeeming oneself for past crimes, and specifically in the case of murder, by saving a life through a bone marrow transplant. However, I can't help but feel like there's an element of exploitation...especially when the incentive is set up to give the prisoner better 'conditions'. I wonder if there is a more suitable incentive. Thoughts?
Thanks Crystal. I just applauded Evan and left a comment. I think all prisoners have a tough spot and a soft spot. I think this speaks to their soft spot.
Hey David, take a look at Evan Brom's Bones for Freedom concept. I think both of you are on to something that can not only help one in need of bone marrow but also help prisoners rehabilitate.

comments.text: Thanks for the support and builds!@Megan: yes, Tough Mudder would be a perfect event for this. Thought of this concept as a way to leverage people's perceptions about the "toughness" of completing a bone marrow donation@Joy: nice point about these event participants overindexing on healthiness. And glad to get confirmation from your personal experience that fundraising walk participants are often looking for ways to do more to make a difference.

I really like this idea for a couple of reasons:1) Because, in a way, it is targeted recruitment of healthy potential donors.and 2) If you are recruiting at fundraising events (runs/walks) for cancer, participants and attendees likely have personal connections to the disease and are probably looking for more ways to make a difference.  I worked for a national breast cancer fundraising walk and had the great fortune to get know many of the participants.  So many of them walked as a way to make a contribution and were always looking for ways to do more. I'm sure the opportunity to become a registered bone marrow donor would resonate with this audience.Nicely done!

Makes me think of another event: http://toughmudder.com/They pride themselves on the "not everyone can do this" mentality. This could be spun to the matching process.  Everyone can register, all you have to do is swab your cheek.  Not everyone can be a match. Are you tough enough to save a life?It's a different approach than the mass targeting, but an interesting concept.

comments.text: First of all, thank you all for your comments!Krassimira, maybe the right question to ask is: how to create an environment where  people would spontaneously, genuinely (or even unconsciously) be helping those who have cancer. Instead of telling them "please donate" (as in "please exercise, and eat healthy food"), transform the environment around them to make them WANT to donate (as they would want to walk, bike, etc.).Sina, great idea! Kind of like what we are doing now on OpenIDEO, except with a focus on the campaign itself :)Benjamin, thanks for the link, I think it's a very interesting idea! It's a great to see that you've posted it as an inspiration, I am sure it will draw a bunch of new questions/build-ons from other OpenIDEATORS.

Great inspiration Sarah. I think focusing on the "donator experience", making it easier/convenient for him to donate, could bring a lot of value.Btw this reminds me of the "ability" part of B.J. Fogg behavior change framework at Stanford : http://www.behaviormodel.org/

Sarah, don't have to sell me hard on good design as a gerat way to tackle the problem of drawing positive attraction to conventionally unfamiliar or "unattractive" issues that have question marks! AWESOME idea. To build a little: would be cool if there was a crowdsourcing competition for branding design (i know a defacto one emerged when Gap put out that tacky logo; but a coordinated one would be another way of getting people to think about marrow donation with creativity as well).

Sarah, this is a lovely idea! Could this be translated into an idea as to how to reduce the number of people suffering from cancer? how to create an environment around us/in us, so that this can be achieved?

department_of_motor_vehicles_and_marrow.description: Hate waiting forever at the DMV (Department of Motor Vehicles)? What if, when you are filling out your car registration or driver's license application(which often includes opt-in or mandated choice questions for organ donor & voter registration), you are also asked whether you want to do a cheek swab on the spot to register as a bone marrow donor? If you do, you’d get a cool bones badge on your driver’s license (next to the heart showing you’re an organ donor), keychain, license plate, or bumper sticker to spread awareness (and perhaps swaying the nice officer who pulls you over for a traffic violation to let you off with a warning), but you also get put to the front of the line.
department_of_motor_vehicles_and_marrow.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: This is such an important issue to address, and I think with a bit of planning this could be a simple and effective change to implement.
Congrats on the winning concept Vincent. A practical, implementable solution to such a daunting issue; very impressive.
Thanks for the vote of confidence Adam =) Hope 100K Cheeks, the Haas Center, & OpenIDEO can bring these promising concepts towards realization to save more lives!
Hey Vincent, thanks for pulling the inspiration through to a winning concept! well done!
Thanks Kate. Nice insight on your inspiration =).
Vincent, good job! Congrats!
Thanks Krassimira! You've really been rocking on the challenges as well. In particular for marrow registration, I'd love to see some more hero registration gifts out there: http://bit.ly/eCXI9x

Ashley--one way to get started would be to reach DonateLife.net, the organization Vincent mentions, for ideas and assistance. There is contact info (both at the national and state level) on their website. And when it comes to reaching out to lawmakers, you might consider an approach such as the one used by New York Sen. David Carlucci and Assemblyman Felix Ortiz--make it personal: http://tinyurl.com/3o4t5xhCongratulations Vincent for a great idea.

Absolutely what I was thinking Gaynelle!In addition, when lobbying, may be helpful to begin with those who have been helping pass state legislation for the 2006 Uniform Anatomical Gift Act ( http://uniformlaws.org/Act.aspx?title=Anatomical%20Gift%20Act%20(2006) ), which streamlines organ donation practices to allow & encourage driver's license donor registration. 20 states enacted this in 2007 and more state continue to introduce and enact it (2011 includes Maryland, Massachusetts, & Pennsylvania). Lawmakers who supported this are likely to be sympathetic to marrow registration as well.

One of the things the OpenIDEO team discussed with the Haas Center and 100K Cheeks was the question of how this idea might actually start getting implemented. Could someone create a petition drive? Could we lobby local and state politicians? How might we think about taking this concept "off the pages" of OpenIDEO and into real life?
Definitely good concept, I like the incorporation of the registration through a common. Congratulation !

I think Vincent's idea to promote the bone marrow registry and conduct cheek swabs at DMVs is worth pursuing. A drivers license must be the most commonly used form of identification in the US.  Piggy-backing on an existing infrastructure that people are already involved in and familiar with (regardless of age, ethnicity, class, urban/rural residence, etc.) may reach people who might be missed through other forms of outreach. A driver's license requires regular renewals, unlike a Social Security card, and individuals' contact with their DMV is scattered throughout the year (unlike a Census, which happens at the same time for everyone and requires a lot of temp workers to implement).   A challenge would be to work with each state to implement the program.

I really like this idea of using the DMV to increase registrations because people are already "primed" for indicating organ donation as part of getting or renewing their license. I offered the comments below in the evaluation template, but thought it might be helpful to have them here as well.I think there is a difference between donating organs after you're deceased (easier to contemplate because we really don't think too much about it, it appeals to our altruistic nature, and it doesn't require any real effort on our part once we're "gone") versus donating stem cells or marrow which involves a real commitment in terms of time and effort. In other words, marrow donation is an "active" commitment versus a more passive one. In an effort to remove some of the potential barriers / objections to registering, you might consider offering a "choice" of the type of stem/marrow donor you'd be. While the default selection for the DMV donor organ program is that any organ or tissue may be used, they do offer the ability to check off a "donor limitations" option. With the "Be The Match" marrow registry, by signing up you are agreeing to donate via PBSC or marrow transplant. While the PBSC donation may be similar to a blood draw (although it is a bit more involved because it requires several days of filgrastim shots prior to the stem cell collection), the marrow transplant requires general anesthesia or regional anesthesia (spinal or epidural) and potentially an overnight hospital stay. It seems like the greater degree of commitment required for a bone marrow donation may give people second thoughts about registering. What if potential donors had the ability to specify they'd be a PBSC donor or a PBSC + Marrow donor. Perhaps as a PBSC donor they indicate they'd be willing to be contacted if a marrow donation was required. (In other words, provide an "opt-in" for a marrow donation, rather than automatically agreeing to this more complicated procedure.) It strikes me that people might be more ready--particularly in a DMV environment--to sign up for something similar to a blood donation than they would be to sign up for a donation requiring a surgical procedure. And if its true that 80% of donations are done via PBSC, then you could think of this as serving the majority of the people needing this type of donation. The unknown in this equation is how many people don't register because they would need to commit to donating via either method, and if the option to register for a PBSC donation only would lower the barriers to registering. Applauded your efforts!

Thanks so much Gaynelle for your thorough and thoughtful comment! Not only is your suggestion to provide PSBC vs. marrow donation options a potential optimization for this concept, but its also broadly applicable to most of the marrow registration concepts in this challenge.I agree itd be great to get the data on follow-through for these different scenarios, whether through pre-existing research or a live experiment (as I doubt a self-report survey would be accurate here). That way wed be able to make an informed decision on how best to present registration options.Thanks again for your astute analysis! Hope to see more of it here in the future =)
very clever - as with another one of your ideas - you've done a good job of capitalizing off of existing infrastructure, procedures/routines, and people flow.

I really like the link here of the responsibility you have as a driver as well as as a person that is old enough to drive a car. I find especially for young drivers who just got their license, this is a great moment to raise awareness. Megan, great point that the focus might get lost. Maybe renaming/re-positioning it - less organ/bone marrow donor but rather "social responsibility" or even a more catchier phrase -  to simply ask: What are you willing to contribute? You are (in the case of the younger) now old enough to decide!

After your last comment, I understood what you meant.  I like the idea about combining the 2 within the registration process.  I wonder if the message gets lost with advertising for both though. That's why I focused on just one. Anyone else want to weigh in?
Think this is a great way to reach a larger audience that is already giving in some form.  I wonder where else we could have these packets available too.

Thanks for the support everyone! There's definitely a natural linkage between marrow registration and the pre-existing organ donor opt-in on driver licenses. @Sarah: glad to here that this would have worked for you =). Great build about having bone marrow-specific awareness raisers target busy DMV's with relevant underrepresented populations. Also, even if these folks can't be at all DMVs, the information, swab kits, and incentive system could still be implemented throughout the system (since the process is simple enough that Be The Match already recruits people online by getting them to sign up for mailed self-registration kits).

Yes! I am just getting my driving license in the US and signed up for organ donation, I would have signed up for bone marrow too. I spent so much time waiting that I could have easily gotten my swab taken too while I was there.  Bone marrow folks can't be at all dmv's always, but perhaps they could do a rotation once a week and if at any one time there was a shortage for a particular type of patient, perhaps they could focus on dmv's in areas with relevant populations.It's all about making it easy.
I really like this idea. As I was reading through some of these concepts, I thought - this is kind of like the organ donor thing on the back of your license and the voila your concept.
I like the idea of connecting it to drivers licenses as bone marrow donation makes me think of organ donation and thus the DMV - makes sense!

py/tuple: How easy is this concept to implement?
I could start right now.
This might take a bit of planning and probably some help from several partners.
This is a big undertaking and I'd need a lot of help from friends, organizations and other groups to make it happen.
Will this concept successfully reach and encourage under-represented populations (including South Asians) to join the bone marrow registry?
Yes, this concept will resonate with diverse groups of people from all over the world.
No, this concept might not reach under-represented populations very well.
I'm not sure, but I hope so!
How well does this concept dispel myths, ease fears, or provide education about bone marrow registration and donation?
Really well -- I already feel like I have a better understanding of the process and why it's important.
Okay, though it'll still take some explaining to get people to understand how bone marrow registration and donation work.
Not very well -- we'd have to create a highly detailed plan around this concept to help people understand.
How scalable is this concept?
This concept is highly scalable and could easily impact people all over the world.
This concept is really best suited for small groups and local areas.
This concept could be scaled, but we'd have to refine it for different settings.

Great idea Chris. Visually, the 1st image is really working for me. Definitely evokes mystery/curiosity. This could work well, both as a physical pin, as well as online as a status icon, profile photo, blog badge, etc. Maybe something like a happy looking red heart could be added above it for a completed donation?

nick_naming_bone_marrow_.description:
Usually people are not too aware of what 'Bone marrow' really is, and the name can be misleading as something which will never grow back once it's taken out from the body. 

The re-naming campaign to brand bone marrow as something friendlier towards future donors.
nick_naming_bone_marrow_.creator: 5cc82464bdb542c1a936d824806ed1b6

comments.text: Fantastic names! It's really interesting to see how this concept is being developed!
BondMarrow!
BeMarrow!
Marshmarrow!

I like this comment thread. So much interaction. Cool!How about, building on Justin's marshmellow: - bone-mellow. Or, to connect it to the lifesaving capabilities: Lifemellow. Live mellow, give your lifemellow.Might also take the focus off of painful procedures.

Could you just use 'marrow', a lot of cultures are familiar with marrow in terms of cuisine, so it may also be an avenue to connect with underrepresented groups in encouraging donation as well--and its kind of similar to the red bean example. The world Bone has a kind of visceral reaction of pain, that I feel in my bones as I write this--maybe taking just that word out might suffice?
How about we reclaim the acronym "BM" for something other than what often happens in public swimming pools when little children are present?

Loving this free-flowing re-branding session folks - great work! Perhaps it might spark some of you to post new concepts that showcase some of these potential names? Think logo sketches, print ads, social media badges - how might we visualize our new names for bone marrow?

Great concept, Justin. Relating the issue to everyday FMCGs, Mars changed the 'Marathon' to the 'Snicker' simply because the name was selling the chocolate bar. coming up with a fun, modern, accessible name can make such a difference and gives a great excuse to get a marketing campaing launched!! Maybe the first part is to set a competition going to get the public to come up with a name. this would give the chance to explain the barriers faced and get them shifted!Well done!

Thanks for your feedbacks guys,Jennifer - Very valid point, the fact that the PBSC is a nonsurgical procedure needs to be notified through the name, otherwise people will easily picture the donation as something 'surgical' therefore 'painful'. Also, the name could reflect the fact that the donor can get back to the normal routine in just one or two days (if he/she faces any side effects) but could save lives. Once the right nickname is given to bone marrow, whether it's jelly, pudding or marshmallow, it could be nick-named like.. 'jelly gathering' or something like that! Thanks Jennifer, great input.Jinsop - Bone jelly is good, isn't it? let's see how others think!Larry - Cheers! Sarah - The same here, I don't exactly know why, but I keep on thinking about food as well when I think about nicknaming bone marrow. There may be a good reason why 'Apple' and 'Red beans' are used to describe other parts of our body!Karen - Love your illustration board, and I agree with you about the importance of the education! Thanks!It's getting exciting to see what nick name bone marrow could have, and would love to hear more! cheers!

I like this idea, plus there is no name congruence right now between the two methods of donation: PBSC donation and bone marrow. The new name(s) should reflect that the two methods accomplish the same thing, and the PBSC donation name could be changed to reflect that this is the easier method, and one most people would do.

Thanks Larry.  Sarah, gruyere may not be mainstream enough as a nickname but I am liking the honey/jelly/jam approach.  All things I'd like to share with others!  Perhaps we could combine honey and pudding?  Or just bone-jelly? Or bone-pudding?  We've had 117 views, so I hope more people put up their ideas for nicknames!
Just saw this after seeing Karen Lin's. Definitely you guys are on to something.

To me, bone marrow looks like a honeycomb, or something with lots of cavities, like a piece of gruyre. And also like honey, jelly, jam or something like that, as far as the texture/thickness is concerned.(Don't get me wrong, but I just can't stop thinking about food since the new challenge has been posted).

Doht! I just saw your concept and I submitted a similar one about expanding the call for bone marrow to something beyond.. bone marrow. Totally agreed that it's not an appealing term itself and could use a new reputation. Gonna go update mine to "build on this" with yours. Thanks!
haha, Jinsop, pudding sharing is excellent!

Hey Justin, thanks for posting this.  I likey the marshmallow.  This actually forced me to google-image bone marrow since I had no idea what the stuff looks like...I go with 'pudding' or a combination of two words involving the word pudding.  Everyone likes pudding, no?  And it's something that sounds easy and pleasant to share...

Hey Ashely, glad to hear this got your brain whirling, would you have any suggestion? Maybe we could invite others for their input on what other alternative name Bone Marrow could have. My go ; Marshmallow. - for being a soft, spongy tissue found inside the bones!
Red beans?! That's brilliant! Definitely gets my brain whirling to think about what we could call bone marrow instead :)

nick_naming_bone_marrow_.title: Nick naming Bone Marrow

why_donor_i.description:
*a play on the question “why don’t I?” (donate) and tapping into the expanding mobile application era + service designs as a motivator to increase donors.*

A location based service solution that concentrates on using local donor information, collected through the service, to help promote and bring a sense of presence (and community connection) to the people that live and commute around you and their experiences in becoming bone marrow donors. The service eases the donor process by providing up-to-date simple visualised donor information. In the end, this will help to demystify the myths of the donor process and increase new donors.
why_donor_i.creator: 22deecc091f4459a686ebadb762522bb

comments.text: Thank you all for your comments and suggestions.

Really great concept, seriously well considered and thought out!Could the local stats like the '1 in 20 people on this bus are registered...' be something that could update live also so you could directly see the number of locals registered? It seems it would be good in a couple of ways. 1. Addressing people's fears, if you know many people who are your community are registered it could be reassuring. 2. Areas would enter into a group mindset of registering which would help raise awareness. 3. A competitive edge could appear between areas on a nearby/national or even global level.But this is just one little suggestion, you've done an amazing job on the concept, I really love it!

Aaron,I really like this concept!  I was actually thinking of something similar with respect to using location based services.  Something like this...Patients/families or their care providers (transplant coordinator, social worker, patient navigator, doctor, etc) can add a patient to the list of "patients in need."  The patient would need to give consent.  Need to determine what attributes are supplied to the service, but, location would be required such as zip code or city.  Then, when a user "checks-in" using apps such as foursquare or enters a designated are they would receive a notice on the Why Donor I app announcing a patient in need is in the area.  The user could also view other patients in need that may be out of their area too.  The user would have available to them all of the options you've described on how to get swabbed. In addition, if donor centers or (DKMS), donor recruitment orgs or registries (Be The Match, Gift of Life, etc) could partner with strategic locations to have swabs on site the user could literally get swabbed on the spot after completing simple health screening questions using the app.  For example, a restaurant would be trained on swabbing or distributing the swab kit.  This way the user can take immediate action and support the patient in need.  This could be expanded to all types of locations.  If I understood correctly from your concept, advertisements and special offers would be provided to users via the app.  This is an important piece as I see this bringing in money from advertisers to pay for the lab and overhead costs.  Also, the app should support financial donations to allow users to contribute monetarily as well as getting swabbed. The idea of offering a consultation in person or phone with a health professional is fantastic.  Informed consent is a very important part of the process.  To have someone back out after they are found to be a match can be devastating for the patient.Great idea!
Awesome concept Aaron! I'm loving the time and thought you put into this, especially the idea that the app might help notify people when a patient match has been found. Great work!

is_music_genius_in_your_dna.description:
Challenge cross-disciplinary teams at Stanford to build a computer program that could create music from a visual representation (i.e., musical score) of a registrant’s DNA.

Use the program to let people download their DNA masterpiece as an MP3 file.  Or, find what musical genius’s symphony or pop song they most closely match. Create songs with their friends’ and family members’ DNA scores.  Make ring tones. The possibilities are endless.
is_music_genius_in_your_dna.creator: 0f061ef28def7bb4e0dece96b4374a66

comments.text: This is really cool idea. It totally reverses the risk:reward ratio that Emily Friedberg mentioned in Inspirations. I would love to see how my DNA looked when mapped to music. It would also be amazing to create some sort of database, like the Pandora Genome Project, that will allow users to listen to and download other donors and donees DNA compositions. Literally turning the basic building block of life into a work of art!

Hello Joana,I'll encourage you and your friends to download our iPhone App GeneGroove (free) which plays a music melody from genome data, not from pictures, yet. Data needs today to come from a 23andMe test, but GeneGroove next versions will be data agnostic.Our Genomic Music sounds lounge, electro and house today but will move to other genres later.We'd love to hear from you at Portable Genomics (creators of GeneGroove) and see how we can move this field forward. Cheers and congratulation for your work.
Brilliant!

@ lyobosa: Excellent thoughts... After hearing a lot of simple algorithm based music compositions which sound monotonous like beeps from a machine... I think a lot of "cheating," randomization etc. is needed to make something that sounds like music. People think they're listening to their DNA, but it's not like they're listening to a simple mapping of DNA into sounds (which would sound monotonous). This project would probably work great with DNA analysis folks having music as a hobby - and computer science folks having music as a hobby, and of course, musicians. Music could be the common ground, while each profession informs the design. You could use only parts of the DNA to create the music, and not the whole thing. This project sounds very exciting to me, because I compose music and have a computer science background.

Nice.  I like the way you've described the conversion process in that it's not going to be an exact, direct translation of DNA.  Creative license would be a big part of the process of creating the conversion program as far as the way that certain sequences translate to phrases or harmonies and how those are mixed or randomized.  I think you're totally right that that is why the teams to create the program would need to be interdisciplinary and/or include people with knowledge and interest in both music and programming/other things because it's pretty wide open as far as how DNA samples would actually translate to notes and musical phrases.  Thanks for lending your expertise!

This is an exciting idea. How would you handle privacy issues? In the current process, people are afforded a huge degree of confidentiality. This would make the DNA profiles of individuals public allowing it to be data mined for several unintended purposes. Even if kept anonymous, if the conversion score is public--or if it can be decoded--this would end up being an extremely sought after database of information on people's genetic make up. Given that DNA is the ultimate identifier---there could be serious unintended consequences.

Hey Iyobosa.  That's a really great question and one that I've been thinking about as well.  For legal reasons, everyone involved with the competition/process of creating the conversion program would have to sign legal contracts ensuring privacy and the forms required for any sort of testing/interviewing using human subjects.  Obviously, people who are registering would not be forced to have a song created for them, so those that had big concerns about privacy could still register without requesting a song.  I think that although the algorithms to create the program to convert DNA into songs might be open/public (but not necessarily), someone would have to have a very specific skill set and the determination to create a program to convert it in the other direction (songs to DNA).  I feel like this might be the same as a lot of the information on the web, which could be accessed if someone were skilled and determined enough.You bring up a good point about the privacy issues.  As far as I know, there are different ways  to capture DNA, which produce different amounts of information about a person.  Someone much more knowledgeable than me would have to assess what sort of sample would be gleaned from a cheek swab and whether it would cause potential privacy issues in the future.  Currently, I believe that you need a pretty detailed sample that breaks down all the proteins and such in order to determine potential private issues like diseases and legitimacy of birth.Good thinking on this...you've really challenged me to more fully consider one of the big feasibility questions for this concept.  I'd love to hear if you have more thoughts or have done more research into this!

What I love about this concept is that it takes a serious scientific endeavor and humanizes it through art. Science and art are two halves or a whole; together they represent the human in her entirety. This solution brings together those two halves in a lovely and collaborative way. Very nicely done. Kudos.

Hey all,  thanks so much for the feedback and additional ideas!Crystal - love it!  Definitely pushing the idea forward in terms of creating some sort of Pandora-like online database from the DNA songs (Pandora is awesome!).  I'd love your help in thinking through how that would work. :)Keme - awesome idea...I like how it kicks up the interactivity one notch.  I'll definitely incorporate that into the next update.
You could ping your DNA soundtracks on itunes between friends letting them know that you've donated and encouraging them to do the same and then get their own musical DNA map :-)
Genius!
I love this concept! I would definitely want to know how my DNA sounds like :)
Very poetic concept!  it!

connect_donors_and_patients.description: To make bone marrow donation more personal and emotionally resonant, how about we develop opportunities to connect patients in need with people considering donation?

comments.text: I think this is a great idea Ashley. In the same way that the Kiva model has been so successful (albeit slightly misleading) in terms of adding a personal element to microfinance, a similar idea could be used for those in need of bone marrow transplants. I agree with Johan that there would likely be legal issues involved but Im sure those waiting to receive transplants would be enthusiastic about an project that might increase the likelihood of finding a donor. Best of luck throughout the rest of the process

Yes, I really love this idea. But some will say it is impossible because of laws, medical confidentiality and patients integrity reasons.So, just do a virtual match. You do connect one donor together with one survivor that received a transplant. But these two could be totally unrelated and not even matching their same type of marrow. The one thing they have in common is the connection that they could be the donor-recipient.(see also my idea that i built upon this concept)

connect_donors_and_patients.title: Connect Donors and Patients

starbuck_s_symbol_for_life_interactive_c.description: Starbucks (or anyone else for that matter), adds the "symbol for life" fiducial marker to their cups. Symbol for life cup users browse (using either a mobile device, portable computer or desktop) to Starbucks' home page and click on the "symbol for life" button to launch the fudicial reader camera application. Users hold the symbol for life portion of their cup up to the screen and a patient profile appears on the screen to solicit registration.
starbuck_s_symbol_for_life_interactive_c.creator: 81bdd23f02be16953b223fbb3f523b62

comments.text: What an interesting, interactive way to educate people and share patient stories! Great idea Ryan.

You're absolutely right about the aestethics. I was thinking that you could put the QR code in the middle of the symbol for life. So that it looks nicer than just the QR code.Same to you about St Patrick's day :)

Totally, the fiducial is a type of QR code. I just chose it because I found it more aesthetically pleasing. Although, I think QRs have a wider range of variability and are probably more appropriate for something like the above. Thanks for the feedback and happy just-past-saint-patty's-day!

Great idea. I really like it. Like the related business card concept, it would possibly be a good idea to include a QR code in the Symbol for Life, so that you can read it and be directed to the profile immediately.I like the concept.

starbuck_s_symbol_for_life_interactive_c.title: Starbucks' Symbol for Life Interactive Cups

register_while_you_wait.description: Leveraging retail and other transaction spaces for bone marrow donor education, motivation, and registration.
register_while_you_wait.creator: c54a0fdc47a8063e779917936e4e5e04

comments.text: Hi Jonathan, sorry this input is a bit late but how about incorporating it with ATM machines. One I used the other day asked me if I wanted more information on donating a % of my cash to a charity... they're also used for mobile phone top up stations - captive audience!?

Hey Louise, interesting suggestion to bootstrap on to ATM machines to get the word out. And it's cool to consider how this might play out in banks-- that's a great addition for environments where people wait.
Really nice updates here Jonathan. Thanks for great work on this concept.
Thanks Ashley!

Great to see this made the shortlist - well done Jonathan. As to your question - where do we start? Well, where do people spend most of thier time waiting for service? I find a lot of my time is spent waiting on the phone. What if you had a hold or queue message that explained the donor process and offered the person on hold the opportunity to be tested? Otherwise in the physical world of waiting for service, you probably want to target places where people sit and wait rahter than stand and wait - how about at ball games before the game? You could use the jumbo screens to deliver the message.

Hey Cliff, thanks and love the idea to use phone queue waiting time to play a recording that explains the donor process. Really simple and powerful. We'd need to think through a few things -- the abrupt transition in the middle of a recording to a representative, the voice and authorship of the message -- but those are all think-throughable and this is a great start. And focusing on sit down and wait time -- that's another great refinement.

Hey Cliff, thanks and love the idea to use phone queue waiting time to play a recording that explains the donor process. Really simple and powerful. We'd need to think through a few things -- the abrupt transition in the middle of a recording to a representative, the voice and authorship of the message -- but those are all think-throughable and this is a great start. And focusing on sit down and wait time -- that's another great refinement.

Hey all, thanks for the really thoughtful comments. I love how you're all curious about which contexts are most ripe for more exploration.Arjan and Tristan suggested waiting areas of one kind or another: dentist waiting rooms (for an appointment), taxi cabs (point a to b). Combined with a verbal and direct call to action (Nancy has an important point), focusing this concept on waiting areas might be an interesting thread to follow... So where do we wait? Let's start a list! :)/*Places Where We Wait*/- Medical waiting rooms (appointments)- Transportation (for departure and in transit)- Entertainment venues (showtimes)- Restaurants (food delivery)- Auto repair- DMV (and other gov services)- To use public bathrooms- Shared gym equipment- Supermarket checkout lines- Amusement parks- HairstylingMaybe we should focus on one of these contexts and update this concept? My gut tells me hairstyling, entertainment venues might be interesting given the appeal to increased reputation within a peer group...What do you guys think would be a good candidate to start?

Using waiting time - how about the time you spend on public transport waiting to get from point A to point B? If an advertisement for donations could be placed above selected seats, and registration cards for test kits filled out and deposited into a box on the tram or train, that might work too. And now I am imagining a whole cinema audience waiting for the movie to start, an advertisement comes up on the screen telling a powerful personal story from a donation recipient, and then directs you to the registration card in the pocket on the back of the seat in front of you.

I think the interesting challenge with this idea is figuring when people are most receptive to this type of "in place advertisement" and how to get them to actually want to pick up the information & read it.  Somehow tabloids sell magzines  and little kids get their moms to buy candy, while the person is in line at the supermarket with nothing else to do.  It'll be interesting to figure out when folks are most receptive to picking up a pamphlet & what catchy slogan would catch their eye.  A lot of stores have Aids Walk pamphlets at the cash register or donation buckets, but I wonder how many people actually pick them up.

I like this idea.  Not sure a burger joint is the wait I'd be picking -  I reckon they'd do it for a day, but not ongoing... but the idea of using idle time is excellent.  I'm trying to think of somewhere we all go once to twice a year and have to wait.  GP offices seem perfect.  Dentists maybe... perhaps even barber shops.  I know I'm always bored there and start playing with my phone.
Awesome concept Jonathan! And great white board sketches :)

Love the user journey. Makes it very tangible. And I think it's a great idea to leverage waiting time. Nowadays there's also often a screen showing a specially made program in fast-food restaurants, hotel lobby's and even taxi's. Would be nice to leverage that as well. Show a video. Or put it on the placemats they put on the trays. You get your order, some napkins, a straw for your drink and a swab kit. So you can think about it over dinner. Or in taxi's. Get a swab kit with special envelop, swab while you're taken to your destination, put everything in the envelop and that in a mailbox. I could add a concept for that, but I think it's better that if you think it's a good example, you incorporate it in yours.

register_while_you_wait.title: Register While You Wait

py/tuple: How easy is this concept to implement?
I could start right now.
This might take a bit of planning and probably some help from several partners.
This is a big undertaking and I'd need a lot of help from friends, organizations and other groups to make it happen.
Will this concept successfully reach and encourage under-represented populations (including South Asians) to join the bone marrow registry?
Yes, this concept will resonate with diverse groups of people from all over the world.
No, this concept might not reach under-represented populations very well.
I'm not sure, but I hope so!
How well does this concept dispel myths, ease fears, or provide education about bone marrow registration and donation?
Really well -- I already feel like I have a better understanding of the process and why it's important.
Okay, though it'll still take some explaining to get people to understand how bone marrow registration and donation work.
Not very well -- we'd have to create a highly detailed plan around this concept to help people understand.
How scalable is this concept?
This concept is highly scalable and could easily impact people all over the world.
This concept is really best suited for small groups and local areas.
This concept could be scaled, but we'd have to refine it for different settings.

Crystal, I love the idea of partnering with Whole Foods - you're right, they've already created a culture of giving among their customers and staff. Here's one challenge to consider, though: when I swabbed my cheek, the part that took the longest was actually filling out the paperwork. How might we make it easier to collect the info we need from "cheek swabbers" while they go through the checkout line? Perhaps something to tackle in your next Concept :)

comments.text: I like the idea of having a touring bone marrow bus. In sweden we have touring busses that act as a blood bank which works very well. I also like that this concepts brings abuot a change in the scenary where you live: all of a sudden there's a bone marrow bus in your town. This could create curiousity which could create a buzz and make people joining the movement.

hi_touch_contact_with_people_who_do_not_.description: How do we engage with people who can't donate bone marrow due to infection?
hi_touch_contact_with_people_who_do_not_.creator: 5c76819f30f8c3f27eb6a2efaf1ba0c9

comments.text: Definitely so. I also cant donate. And when I hear anything about blood donation I pay extra attention to that information because it is a reminder. Maybe a way to go would be a a campaign like: "I wish I could donate but I can't".

Definitely so. I also cant donate. And when I hear anything about blood donation I pay extra attention to that information because it is a reminder. Maybe a way to go would be a a campaign like: "I wish I could donate but I can't".

Absolutely. As someone with a few lifelong autoimmune illnesses, I also cannot donate, but have used my power as a professional patient to empathize with those who need donations and explain the importance of registration and donation. to those unfamiliar with it.

Hi John,You may be onto something here. I have had cancer and I can't be a donor now. The first time I tried to donate blood and learned I couldn't, I was very deflated. But....I would definitely be motivated to be on a team that can't swab but wants others to! Good work!janice

hi_touch_contact_with_people_who_do_not_.title: Hi Touch Contact With People Who Do Not Qualify As Donors

comments.text: This ties in really sweetly with the concept about giving peole the option to register while in the dentists, maybe the 2 could combine and become even stronger? The concept is really logical and firmly grounded, well done!

health_in_exchange.title: Health in exchange

comments.text: Ah love the idea of displaying the dreams of people in need of a match -- that reminds me of the girl effect video that went viral http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1e8xgF0JtVg starting around 1:27, the video highlights the positive differences people's help would make in a girl's life (which reflects her aspirations and dreams), differences that otherwise wouldn't have been made possible w/o people's help (sounds like the differences people's marrow donation can make in patients' life!). Either in the form of a public installation or video (or anything really), highlighting patients' dreams might be a good way to deeply engage people and move them. Thanks susan!

Love how this is public, interactive and yet very personal - thanks for the inspiration! Makes me wonder if making the dreams of people waiting to find a match public would be something that would encourage people to register/donate or maybe it's more about celebrating the things people who received bone marrow have accomplished since. Many possibilities indeed!

love the idea! it might be cool to involve donors themselves in the process somehow also e.g. ask a donor to submit a photo of something that has personal significance to him/her. many possibilites here!

I like the idea of making things accessable for everybody! Whoever is brave enough can take part of the installation. How about displaying the donors in some way? You enlighten peoples doing and they get a sort of recognition for what they've done?

comments.text: Certainly an interesting idea, besides being through an appropriate medium in the modern context. Reach is certainly taken care of, and I'm sure appropriate checks and balances to ensure data integrity could be built in. Commendable, because social networking sites could actually contribute their mite.
It would be interesting to have donors have shares in this app based on the number of donors they successfully refer.

comments.text: I am having having trouble using 'build on this' feature, but just posted an inspiration built on this one. http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-number-of-bone-marrow-donors-to-help-save-more-lives/inspiration/lady-gaga-is-dead-/

Getting Shaq on board was a great start.... Has he Tweeted and FB posted about it? Maybe he would add the widget on his FB page.Twitter followers 3,532,551 http://twitter.com/#!/THE_REAL_SHAQFacebook Fans 1,632,124 http://www.facebook.com/Shaq

This is a great idea and I believe has worked to get the initial registrants for the MDRI bone marrow registry in India. They had one of India's most famous actors, Salman Khan, champion their cause and attend the inauguration.
Just imagine if we got Justin Bieber to come... ;)
Wow, creative variation on the typical celebrity spokesperson approach that not only drives awareness, but also provides a significant pull for actual participation.
Thanks Katie! This is a terrific idea, and would definitely attract people's attention!!

organ_donor_pride_how_might_registering_.description: Organ Donor info on one's Driver's License (often a little red heart icon or similar) connects the decision quite literally to who they are or see themselves as. Pretty cool. What other moments are close to this contemplation of self and identity?
organ_donor_pride_how_might_registering_.creator: 68c03a76152dc53fdd2c7c7ab07f2721

comments.text: What if swab kits were offered at the RMV?  People have become highly acculturated to the organ donor request-why not take advantage of this and "piggyback" on with their "ask." Perhaps a short release of info on a driver's license app could trigger a kit to be sent to the driver?  Alternatively, why not give meaningful reinforcement to those who comply-a free oil and filter change at a local shop?  I know that my mechanic "gives" away oil changes as a way to get customers back in the shop on a regular basis.  The free oil change could be a win for the provider as well.  This may also encourage more men to be donors.

Another thought -- what if the sticker was coded visually in relation to your bone marrow profile, so people might compare stickers to see how closely they "match" one another. Im thinking horoscopes or urban myths about bone marrow and romantic compatibility...  Make it better?

Thanks, Nicole. Maybe we could create a small sticker -- some kind of bone marrow registry emblem/icon -- that is designed to be applied to one's driver's license or identification card (?). Other ideas?

Currently, people who register get a card they can keep in there wallet.  I think this is a great idea, and Be the Match should expand upon these efforts.  Keeping India in mind, in all seriousness, Indians really like being recognized for their good deeds.  This is why everybody is an organ donor in India.  If we could play up this idea, it could have big effects

organ_donor_pride_how_might_registering_.title: ORGAN DONOR PRIDE:  how might registering become part of identity (or even identification)?

comments.text: Great point. There are lots of myths to overcome in just blood donation so for bone marrow donation its not surprising to see the hesitation.
Nice observation and great example of how to overcome.

the_q_tip_prize.description: What if boxes of Q-tips hosted a special swab that was an alternate color and locating this in your box meant your test was paid for?
the_q_tip_prize.creator: 05c66869e075a33457a701ebdc853181

comments.text: Carola: Not sure on expiration dates for Q-tips but worth noting!Amy: I would imagine it might be location specific? It begs a question around the idea of where people might connect to the idea of becoming a donor and what types of products/services connect to this. I love the idea of game as a mediator for these things. Scratch and win cards are another area that comes to mind. Safeway recently hosted one and I won something, which required me to go to the store to pick it up. I was engaged with the whole contest even though I won a token prize. What if a lottery were associated with this and you could win your test (or other related prizes) through a scratch and win model? Other thought: What if dentists were one of the motivators for getting people to be tested? Clean teeth, Swab cheek!
I think corporate sponsorship from Q-tip would be great, given the relevance.  Have you researched the life-span of a swab kit? is it something that would expire?
I love the idea of taking something commonplace and integrating a new behavior into it - what else besides Q-tips could we do this with?

Thanks, Vincent/Lin/Louise!I think it would be possible to post a website on a Q-tip as per this inspiration: http://bit.ly/e2DnNyI bet the packaging could also host additional details as well (especially if Q-tip was on board to support the initiative).

Great, Kara and agre with Lin on the surprise element. The nice thing is that even if the user isn't necessarily aware of there being a prize available, having a different coloured Q-tip in the box would get them asking questions. It is a very simple way to make someone think twice about why one Q-tip was different and then such a simple action needs to be taken! Q-tips are very thin but a web address could be printed on the plastic stick to provide more information?
Love the "surprise" effect. What about a personal message from a leukemia patient waiting for the match attached to the yellow Q-tip.
Nice Kara. I like the surprise prize element of this, which frames donation registration as an special opportunity. If I got the prize, I wouldn't want it to goto waste.

the_q_tip_prize.title: The Q-tip Prize

bone_marrow_match_club..description: Similar to the haplogroup discoveries on 23andMe -- what if you could connect with people of similar bone marrow types? You'd likely find you have a lot in common with virtual strangers -- and therefore a larger network of similar marrow donors.
bone_marrow_match_club..creator: 3235e3e7b5e215043e3d5105fef47950

comments.text: This is a great idea, focuses on building human connections. People may be more likely to register and donate if they feel that connection
This is good idea.Thinking of things to build on this......
I like how this builds value in knowing your HLA type.  So rather than expecting altruism, you're giving people something the want.
Cool idea Katie, especially since many people are interested in their personal ancestry/genealogy. In a sense, it's a way of extending the family circle of care outward.

bone_marrow_match_club..title: Bone marrow match club.

donating_as_standard.description: There is this political discussion in Germany right now to make organ donation the standard: When a person dies, his/her organs will be donated except the person expressed his will against it before. Why not adding bone marrow to this idea?
donating_as_standard.creator: cc491de401e5dbcde41ef91090975f42

comments.text: Kevin, thanks for your comment! I agree that it is a sensitive issue and I can very well imagine it would definitely take some time to convince people to switch to an opt-out system.

Hi, Veronika. This is an interesting idea. It's actually a big discussion on whether organ donation should be opt-in or opt-out. In fact, opt-out systems (as often seen in Europe) increases organ donations compared to opt-in systems (such as in the U.S.). My impression was that a huge opposition is expected if we were to switch to an opt-out system in the U.S. But if we can make this happen and include a bone marrow donation at the same time, that would be so awesome!!!

donating_as_standard.title: Donating as Standard
