move4marrow.description: Exposing people to the realities of leukemia and other cancerous diseases whilst simultaneously entertaining the victims through the mediums of dance and theatre.
move4marrow.creator: 7c9206fc89d90a44996ce3d36f9fa139

comments.text: Many people seems to find new places to give awarness about the problem. The theater is a place where you usually sat 10 min before the play begins, so you have their attention. It would be useful to divide the event in 2 parts: first offer the information about the problem  when entering/ buying ticket; second offer a kit to register on the way out. People need time to think about it.I was wondering how expensive are those kit? can we make them cheaper?

Cool idea.  If you're looking for inspiration to develop this concept further, check out The Penelope Project (http://penelopeproject.wordpress.com/about/).  It was a year-long exploration by Sojourn Theatre, the UWM Center for Age & Community, the UWM theater department, and the residents and staff of Luther Manor (a long-term care facility) into the myth surrounding Penelope, from Homer's Odyssey.  The process and resulting play brought out themes of waiting and dealing with memory loss for the residents (many of who were themselves dealing with conditions like dementia) and also made university students and community members more aware of the challenges of aging, as well as the hidden talents of the residents.  It's a really incredible example of how the process of making art can spread knowledge and awareness about an issue, challenge previously held notions, engage inter-generational, diverse populations, and empower under-valued members of a community.

move4marrow.title: Move4Marrow

15_year_old_boy_famous_singer_story_tell.description: Finding an 'ordinary' person who has had experience of bone marrow surgery (?) got through it and teaming them with a celebrity to tell a story can be powerful. Keenan, a 15 year old American kid with a genetic disease which required a bone marrow transplant has become incredibly famous for impersonating famous singers! His YouTube videos have been watched by millions of viewers and celebrities are wanting to make videos with him.
15_year_old_boy_famous_singer_story_tell.creator: 8e84dcee4c3a16638492d06cd11ca88f

comments.text: I'm just seeing this--and Keenan!--for the first time and wanted to say thanks for that (over a year later--thanks internet)! A pleasure. There's something special about the video you chose here, something that seems rare in other collaborations I've seen btwn similar duos...there's genuine 'play' there, enjoyment on both ends. I don't see pity, I see mutual respect. The point where David makes the heart with his hands, that feels real. So often pairings like this feel promotional...a never-ending design challenge I suppose!
Haha, Angelique Kidjo is a personal favorite, and K'naan made fame last year during the World Cup in South Africa. His song also featured in the Coca Cola commercials.
You've got me there, Arjan. I will need to YoubTube them ;-)
How about an artist like Angelique Kidjo or K'naan. His Wavin' Flag song was very catchy.
Yes Arjan! Bollywood is an ace idea - it is sooooo fun and engaging and perfect for the South Asian audience.  Just need a theme/celeb for the African audience....

Louise, just gave you a great evaluation. What a great concept, very well connecting a bone marrow recipient celebrity with promotion. You could also think of involving Bollywood actors in another version. I think that would resonate well with South Asian audiences.Anyway, another campaign by will.i.am that inspired me to a concept, was the In my name campaign. Maybe it's the same as Sina is referring to. For a link to that, see my concept: http://3bl.me/ny4p95 - it has the In my name video in it.

Sina, do you have a link for the 'yes we can' video? I wonder if Beyonce would do a single-ladies-bone-marrow dance which everyone wants to copy! Another thing that comes to mind is once this video has gone viral, everyone will want to be part of it. Could Keenan and the celebrity run a competition which lets other people compete to show their bone marrow story song? Everyone that enters could have to swab first.... Maybe I'm going off track now ;-)

i like how this pairs the attention driving force of celebrity, an the real personage of someone in need or has benefited from donating and receiving donation. there is a lot of potential power here. what about a video like the "yes we can" video by will.i.am? great work Louise!
Thanks for all your helpful comments and links. I'm about to build on this idea further incorporating them.

Hi Carola, I hope it doesn't look like I'm saying surgery is always necessary - the point of using Keenan as an example is because he's had a bone marrow problem and the concept works around him. Yes, he has had surgery but the aim is just to find someone who has been affected to explain that a simple thing like a swab could help someone like them!

An observation from your descriptions: donors or recipients don't have to go through surgery, most of the treatment is done intravenous.  It's important to demystify the process so that people are less fearful of it.
Another good celebrity supporting the cause could be Nelly.  His sister lost her battle with Leukemia a few years ago.
And I can't help but think of Q-Tip as a cool celebrity partner. His name really does fit the cause in many ways.

Hi Amie, to answer your questions, I said it needed a clever story to be written that can be included in the video so that the kid can get a message across. People relate to songs, repeat them and see people like this as a role model. This is a concept that needs refining.

I'm not making the connection between clever cut through video humour and awareness-raising around bone marrow transplants? I'm also not sure how it addresses the fear and misunderstandings surrounding such transplants.
Thank you for sending the link!  I think this exactly the right combination of a story and visual medium that will get people to pay attention.
Thanks for the links, Ashely and Jonathan. Your links are really helpful for building on this concept. I had no idea of 50cents work with DKMS! #lovelearning

Humor always helps get the message out.  I think getting 50 Cent to join in is a real possibility.  He's already aware about the need from his work with DKMS http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b5NmA8cc6-w&feature=player_embedded

What a great find Louise! I am so impressed by Keenan's story and loved this video. Perhaps there's a way to build on Sina's concept about YouTube http://bit.ly/f6wVms to create a simulation video that features the musical stylings of Keenan?

This concept is really best suited for small groups and local areas.

comments.text: Liking where this is going with the symbol that spreads the word, makes the donor feel good, and can be supported by local businesses (offline and online, as Kim suggested, are very complementary). Great ideating Brett!

Nice post Brett, and great build Kim! Be sure to hold on to these thoughts as we move into the Concept phase next week - where we really start thinking about actual campaigns and other solutions to get more people to register.

I like this idea, it's along the same lines as the little heart on your drivers license that let's everyone know you're an organ donor.  Giving that our social networking profiles have become our public centers of information, that seems like the right place to add an icon for 'I swabbed'.The best part of using social media is that once you do swab, the notice would go out to all your friends/followers which would entice them to wonder what it meant, learn more, and hopefully take action.This would work best if it could be linked to some sort of 'action' link that would allow readers/viewers to get a free swap kit sent to them, or instructions on finding a swab location nearest them to take action.

donors_choose._you_share_journey._a_matc.description: DonorsChooseBM.org is a “project site” that helps bone marrow donors find financial “project” donors to help cover the cost of tissue typing while providing a first-hand perspective of experience. The bone marrow donor makes a project request, which needs to be raised through project donations. The bone marrow donors can share content on the site (posts, pictures, videos, tweets) to inform and inspire donors while gathering donations. Project donors themselves can be prompted to learn more, register to be a bone marrow donor or even create a new project at the time of donation. One the request is matched, the funds are sent to bone marrow donation organizer to initiate the procedure. After a match is made, the bone marrow donor can continue to spread the word by sharing the journey content and/or organizing their own drives to create awareness. Patients and doctors can provide feedback about the transplant and outcomes to both the project and bone marrow donors.
donors_choose._you_share_journey._a_matc.creator: 6aa8273231899c8f19ec42ccc9773186

comments.text: That's a good point Jonathan, knowing how peers relate to reasons for giving can also help match projects to groups of donors, not just individuals!

I really like this concept.  I feel there needs to be a strong platform for actual donors to propagate the reasons why they joined and share their experiences.  The act of joining the registry is sometimes as simple as someone you know did so you're going to do it too.  Potential registrants relate to their peers and we should build on those relationships.

Hi Larry, thanks for your comment. You should definitely check out DonorsChoose.org to see how market-based principles center on donors for public education projects has been an absolute success. DonorsChoose is one of Oprah's favorite things 2010: http://www.donorschoose.org/blog/2010/11/25/oprahs-favorite/.

I like the idea of making this a project for the donors, rather than the recipients. I would have thought to have recipients, or donor drive groups (like finding donors to help a specific recipient) to be the project originators.Its interesting to think about what kind of donors would be motivated (and motivating!) to create a project in this way!

donors_choose._you_share_journey._a_matc.title: Donors choose. You share journey. A match is made, seen and heard.

comments.text: Hi Jon, welcome to OpenIDEO! Yes, building on your first idea with a second Inspiration around leveraging NGOs who provide dental care to low-income communities would be a great idea. One quick tip: for now, try to focus on the existing examples that are out there. For instance, which NGOs are already providing this kind of care that we could learn from/about? Then, once we get into the Concept phase, we can start thinking through what a potential partnership model might look like. It's always so tempting to jump into the possible solutions first! But the Inspiration phase is an important data- and story-collection period for every Challenge. Thanks for your great contributions - excited to see more of your Inspirations soon!

Thanks all for the positive feedback.  Michael my thought is to reach the millions that are in an immediate position to participate effortlessly, that otherwise may not even know about the program.  No single method will reach everyone.  Ashley, I love the idea of partnering with NGO's and I know many dentists that travel out of the country to donate their time and talents to treat underprivileged patients.  Would it make sense to "Build on this" with this idea?  This is my first day and my first post here so I'm not sure of the etiquette.

Great point Michael - we definitely want to think about how to reach people who might not have access to dental care. Still, the fun part about the Inspiration phase is that anything is fair game at this point. Who knows - there might even be a way to partner with NGOs that provide dental care in the developing world to clean teeth and swab cheeks at the same time?! :)

It is not a bad idea but should I remind you the number of millions, world wide, if not billions of people that can't afford dental care nor a descent health insurrance ?Here the idea is to find a cheap or easy way to get 7 billion people knowing about bone marow donation.but as said before nice Inspiration.

Hi Jon, nice Inspiration! If you want to increase your DQ points, you can update your post to build off of this related Inspiration http://bit.ly/eW35Cv. Let us know if you have any trouble with this.

comments.text: I might add this question: How can the donor become an active advocate? I work in the non-profit sector, and one of the primary priorities for development/fundraising is creating a sense of total investment in our donors by turning them into advocates through testimonials (live and recorded) as well as through encouraging and training them to personally perform "asks"  and cultivation of their network. When folks feel like that have something valuable besides money, they realize they are valuable outside of a material context. Philanthropy is also about giving one's time, skill and consciousness.

I can imagine that. I've been a registered donor for a few years now, but after having moved a couple of times, I had to figure out again where and how I was registered. There is actually no communication about it, so I don't feel really connected. It was actually this challenge that made me sort things out again.
Great job interviewing a friend, Megan, and really good questioning here too! These are great questions to keep thinking about throughout this Challenge.

the_lgbtq_community_an_untapped_resource.description: Since 1985 the FDA has banned certain members of the LGBTQ community from donating blood and/or bone marrow.  Specifically, men who have sex with other men or even women who have sex with bisexual men are barred from donating.  Despite the advent of  stringent testing and the changing demographic of those living with HIV and AIDS, this regulation still prevents perfectly viable donors from helping.  Here is an opportunity to fight for two very important causes.
the_lgbtq_community_an_untapped_resource.creator: 9e4f98ab9209b9dfe1f714c3081459d5

comments.text: When I used to give blood regularly in the Netherlands, there was always a short 'medical history' questionnaire. One of the question was about having sex with various partners. I think for blood donation, that is a very valid question in terms of risks of spreading infectious deceases / STD's. Note that the question was about the number of partners in the past 6 months (or so), and not whether it was a same-sex or other type of encounter. Very indiscriminate. In my opinion, saving a life is not a prerogative of heterosexual people, but something anybody should be able to do. Laws like this only decrease the odds for those that need a transplant. Great concept!

the_lgbtq_community_an_untapped_resource.title: The LGBTQ Community: An Untapped Resource

but_does_it_hurt.description: When talking about this Challenge with friends and family, I've been interested to see that the first question many people ask about bone marrow donation is, "Does it hurt"?
but_does_it_hurt.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: Based on what you say, guys, I was thinking that folks who voluntarily go for cosmetic surgery, and expose themselves voluntarily to painful experiences- anethsesia and surgery, might be a good target audience for such a campaign. Maybe such people could be poitential donors with high likelihood to agree when they are found to be a match.

To look at it from a different perspective; sometimes people do things in spite of, or even because of the fact that it hurts and/or possibly endangers your health. Think of smoking, tattoos or piercings. If you emphasize the coolness or toughness of donating instead of emphasizing that they are helping others, you might end up with new donors that otherwise would never donate. Also the likelihood of them following through if they get matched might be bigger because they dont like to be seen as someone who is scared of pain.

Tamar, I like how you deal with this as a 'now' and 'later' question.That said, the amount of money it takes to perform detailed matching is substantial (vetting potential matches in much more detail to see if they are actual matches), so the philosophy has been that we need to find potential donors that have a high likelihood of converting to real donors when the need arises.  Otherwise, the value of the registry is kind of in question -if everybody says "no" when it counts, why bother having them in the registry.If we could change that value equation / perception -make it cheap to be able to have lots of registered potentials say "no" -then maybe that would help lower the bar to saying "yes" to swabs.
Great points Tamar! It's very important to distinguish between the cheek swab (which just puts you on a bone marrow registry) and the actual donation procedure.

I think it's important to make the difference between the process to become a potential donor and the actual donation.  The former involves a mere swipe of a cotton swab in you cheek.  Most people tend to to dwell to much on the future - so, as harsh as it may sound, I think organizations need to focus on the ease of becoming a potential donor.  Learn a bit from politicians - answer the question you want to answer.  The conversation would go like this:Q: "Does it hurt?"A: "Well, it's good you asked!  Becoming a potential donor is actually a very easy process that doesn't hurt at all.  You just swipe a cotton swab on the inside f your cheek and that's it".Q: "Wow! really?  it's that easy?"A: "Yes.  Afterwards, if at any point it time you are found to be a match, someone will contact you and ask you to donate.  If that should happen, the actual donation does have some side effects and there are those who report discomfort after the procedure.  However, this is only in the case that you are found to be a match and agree to donate."Q: " And if I don't agree?A: "Well, that's your right.  And that's it"Q: "OK, then!  Where's that cotton swab?"
So true. Great video.

"But Does it Hurt?" Exactly what I thought when saw the challenge! Seems like lowering the barrier of donation is related to lowering the fear factor.Maybe introducing the use of some kind of placebo could help.
Loving this inspiration! If I hear 'bone marrow donation,' I imagine a scraping, painful, scary process  definitely worth countering thoughts like these.

but_does_it_hurt.title: But Does it Hurt?

register_your_life_saving_stem_cells_tod.description: This concept seeks to rebrand "bone marrow donation" to "life saving stem cells" in order to provide a more accurate picture and drop the prevalent but outdated perception that by registering, you're basically guaranteeing yourself a very painful & scary procedure where your bone is drilled into to remove the contents inside. This is outdated because, a) 80% of the time, stem cells are now simply collected from the blood in an outpatient procedure, and b) when a true bone marrow draw is necessary, the procedure has been improving to become less painful than imagined.  Sample messaging (which still aims for accuracy to ensure registrants are relatively committed, and includes an encouragement to donate cord/placental blood as well) below:

Especially if the registration was related to health, it might spur more interest and participation in marrow donation.  For example, one might register as a donor during health insurance applications or STD screenings--places in which medical information and signatures are already being provided.

redesigning_blood_donation_bags.description: A new way of looking at the bags used to collect donations of blood.
redesigning_blood_donation_bags.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: The other day I was drivng by Mass General Hospital and there was a blood drive bus parked outside the hospital. I was with my sister, who is a Med Student, and I commented on how scary and dirty those buses look - she agreed. I asked her if she had ever donated blood and similar to me, she has not. Why? Because the Blood donation buses are unappealing, unsanitary looking, and the experience as a whole is not inviting. Implementing mobility in blood drives is great, however, it is outdated. I think that redesigning the blood donation experience is so important. Everything from the blood donation bags  (which is such a wonderful start) to the "location" of the donation. Furthermore, if you want people to start donating at the earliest age possible, then the experience MUST speak to all age demographics - and I do not believe that it currently is.

I think it would be AMAZING to redesign the entire blood donation experience.  For doing something so powerful, you'd like a more personalized experience that makes you feel a little bit less uncomfortable.  The cookies and juice are not enough.

This definitely looks less scary than the regular bags! Though the swabs (which are kind of like extra-long q-tips) probably don't intimidate most people, many people think of scary spinal tap procedures and surgeries when they think of bone marrow donation. (See the "does it hurt?" inspiration and the dispelling myths inspirations that have been posted so far.) So maybe we can think of ways to more attractively package the idea of bone marrow donation?

I like the idea of good design on everyday hospital items. Getting blood drawn is not a fun or appealing thing to do.  The labeling is an excellent idea, as is the very attractive package.  Combines form with function nicely.Anything that can give the donor a better experience is helpful and can start good conversations with the health care worker.Nice idea Jan about the pyramid thought.

I like the "thank you" on the container. I also like the shape....it looks a lot more attractive than those old-fashioned floppy plastic bags. Maybe the shape of this container can inspire a campaign for bone marrow transplants? Since it's triangular shaped...there's the donor, the swab or blood draw and the recipient. Or maybe a more compelling middle of the triangle? But could it be a pyramid to build on?thanks!

Great inspiration Ashley, I think it's great to think about inspiration from other kinds of donation, and how it might inspire the 'touchpoints' of the whole donation experience, perhaps not the actual bone marrow donation process, but certainly things like how cheek swabs are collected for instance.

Hi Nicole, thanks so much for your comment and for joining our new challenge!I uploaded this inspiration as part of our Assignment #2, which is meant to draw broadly on our collective experiences donating or receiving any kind of physical donation (bone marrow, blood, organs etc). You're absolutely right that bone marrow donation is its own unique process and experience. We're still working on how to best showcase these Assignments (a new feature launched today) so that it's clear which Inspiration matches up with which Assignment. Thanks again for your comment and I'll look forward to seeing you online throughout the Challenge!- Ashley

This is a great idea, but is not relevant to bone marrow donation.  Bone marrow can be donated through a process that is similar to donating blood, called PBSC.  It is a process that takes a few hours, and stem cells are isolated with a machine and then siphoned back into the individuals body.  Really cool idea though.

donate_bone_marrow_get_credits_from_your.description: This is an idea suggesting a points-based system for a health insurance promotion. Even minor surgeries might put you in a more expensive insurance rate, but when you donate blood or bone marrow, you can earn points and get discount in return. The insured person can exert influence on the insurance conditions while donating for a good cause thanks to this dynamic points system.
donate_bone_marrow_get_credits_from_your.creator: cc491de401e5dbcde41ef91090975f42

comments.text: Arjan, thanks for the feedback! Extra points for people who actually donate bone marrow would definitely make sense! I am also sure insurers would need to research the idea but as there are high costs as well to keep up medical treatments of a patient waiting for bone marrrow donation, I could imagine there might be a way to find a feasible model for all sides. I wanted to suggest a concept, that would raise awareness on several levels and that would work without a recipient. I think those stories about connecting recipient and donor are very very powerful, but there are also a lot of people who dont want to get into a relation where they might feel guilty etc. For some people, it is more interesting to get the incentive from a third party. As I suggested, the insurance companies as aggregators of all the stories, might also have interest in more (bone marrow) donations, I thought they could be the ones to reward it. So the important part is, that it is just what you take from the health care system and what you give, so just your insurer and you. I will update my concept to point this out a bit clearer!I was actually inspired by parts of the German health insurance system where those kind of incentives and point systems are already quite successful (for regular check ups with your dentist). Thank you for the link to Vincents concept, I think the two would complete each other very well!

Hi Veronika, I just had the same thought. Happy that I found your concept before entering my own :). I think this is a very interesting idea. Insurers could research it thoroughly, but I think that people who donate blood or are registered as donors generally are more aware of their health, and therefore less costly for insurers. You could also consider extra points if someone actually donates bone marrow.By the way, if Vincents idea inspired you, you can link his concept to yours.

thank you for the link to vincents idea, maia! there are indeed some similarities. the German system of regular check ups lowering your health costs inspired me, so maybe there is a simular way of combining the interests of health insurance companies with bone marrow registration/donation. I guessed that on a longterm perspective, it must be more expensive to pay for the medical treatments of a patient waiting for bone marrrow than for those who get the transplantation and that in the end, it might be also financially reasonable this way. but you are definitely right that this would have to be figured out in detail!

This is interesting. Similar idea that uses doctor credits/waivers for agreeing to sign uphttp://bit.ly/g3iH1UIt would be interesting to combine incentives for signing up and for donations. I wonder what the barriers would be from the health insurance/legal standpoint.
susan, thank you for your comment! great to hear that you could see it working!

Fantastic stuff! It seems like such a simple system that benefits all of the stakeholders involved that I can't see why it isn't already happening. What I like best is that you can see the potential for the concept to grow to benefit not only bone marrow registration & donation but many more issues and society as a whole! Really well thought about :-)

donate_bone_marrow_get_credits_from_your.title: Credits from health insurance for BM donation

Great idea! I think this would work well for something like registering to become a bone marrow donor.

Great point Sina, thanks for sharing this. I love the idea of appealing to the emotional side of this - 'giving' and why we give feels central to the core of this challenge. Tapping into motivation is exactly what this video does. Genius.

Awesome.  Inspired. Alex nails it. Here is a case on how to tell stories; it dives into distinct story arcs http://faculty-gsb.stanford.edu/aaker/pages/CoursesHowtoTellaStoryMedia.html

I want all my movie synopsis to be told by Alex. I love this campaign. The African people have a lot going for them and there are a lot of beautiful things going on there, but when Africa is mentioned in the media here in the states, it is from the perspective of need. I'm growing weary of that.
brilliant, energising!
LOL. Me too. I saw this and thought, "Wow. I want to hang out with Alex. All the time."
That was awesome, I want to hug this boy.

got_a_call_from_shaq_and_said_yes_.description:
At the last step of the donation process “Getting ready to donate”-  have a celebrity (Shaq, Cindy Crawford, Eva Longoria, Salman Khan, Jennifer Lopez, Rihanna, Hugh Jackman) call the potential donor.

Receiving a call from a celebrity will be 1) a very stong trigger to say “Yes” for a donation and 2) will be extremely motivational. I believe it will have a huge potential to move the scales in favor of an actual donation. And imagine how many years after that people will people talk about the call they received and the donation they made...
got_a_call_from_shaq_and_said_yes_.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: Thanks, Vincent!

Wow, I just realized the power of this idea to leverage celebrity at a key moment Krassimira, especially with Arjan's builds around providing a great story for the donor to spread. *Applause* Can't believe I glossed over this earlier. Luckily, the community set me straight =)
Sarah, agree....to make this concept successful, for every country we start such a campaign, we'll need local celebrities on htne list to make the call.
I really like Arjan's build, it makes the idea more adaptable. And not only we all don't have the same heroes, but even celebrities are not the same everywhere around the world :)

Arjan, I like your ideas! One way to find out who the heros are is to directly ask those who register. As I'm considering in this concept to send post-registration small survey, one question in the survey would be: Who would you like to be called by? and the person can select a name....

Oh, and forgot to add: it could also be interesting to see if you could register somewhere who the heroes of potential donors are. If you could manage to have someone called by their personal hero, or favorite celebrity, that would be even more powerful. If I would be called by Justin Bieber for example, that would not make an interesting story for me. A call from Chris Martin, or Nelson Mandela, would be something I would tell to anybody. Even strangers in the street ;)
It could also be that by calling the ones likely to donate and giving them a story to tell, that story will help to convince the ones that are maybe less likely to donate.I like the idea!
Stephen, good question...We might use the star power for those who have likelihood around 50%-60%....what are your thoughts?
Do we need the star power for those who are likely to donate?... or from those not likely to donate? ...or from those who are most likely somewhere in the middle?

got_a_call_from_shaq_and_said_yes_.title: Got a call from Shaq and said "YES"

I love this idea as well. Everyone uses Q-tips, so if they did become an or THE official sponsor, the word would spread like wildfire. I also love that it's easy for them to integrate bone marrow support into their existing marketing infrastructure.

comments.text: In addition to knowing where to target campaigns, I think visualization to make the need easier to grasp or make it more personal is important.Other possible maps:- Need for donors/people on the registry by community- Lives saved by community, with selectable stories and pictures of the donor and receiver.

registered_donors_map.title: Registered donors map

bone_marrow_donation_for_dummies_.description: A simple guide book to demystify the bone marrow donation process.  Free download in PDF.
bone_marrow_donation_for_dummies_.creator: c93169f1eb9be7246f990690b5e66b2d
bone_marrow_donation_for_dummies_.title: Bone Marrow Donation for Dummies

build_the_movement_locally.description: The Obama Campaign did it better than almost any other campaign I can recall in the last few years. The team used the myObama system to allow people to create their own profile, connect with other supporters near them, and to reach out to new donors.
build_the_movement_locally.creator: 4e75aa86155d8fbb847893c0ffa0c67d

comments.text: This is a great Idea... Movements started locally thrive on collaboration. These donor movements can actually spread to larger communities purely by word-of-mouth.

build_the_movement_locally.title: Build the Movement Locally

use_the_register_and_win_prizes_formula_.description: Diversify donor registries by tapping into a target audiences priority material incentives.
use_the_register_and_win_prizes_formula_.creator: 6fb26fe30e5aa05c9e13f8d33a963616
use_the_register_and_win_prizes_formula_.title: Use the "Register and Win Prizes!" formula to capture a wider audience

give_more_opportunities.description: Sometimes it is all about what you feel like. Going to the hospital or to the donation place is never on our way + usually friends there were so eager to do it with us have different plans. It is better to catch people suddenly, sometimes.
give_more_opportunities.creator: f663744062e5876058493e584f1dbd3e

comments.text: thanks for comment! you think so? i think at home, online, yes. but if you have kids, other things on mind, get back exhausted from work, it is sometimes hard to focus on things like this. + in a special place like this you have all the service - blood test etc, that can tell you if you're eligible, so it is kinda benefit for you. + it is on your way when you're with company - showing off a bit?

I haven't heard of places being constantly open for registering to donate.  If people get the urge to donate they typically can online.  Because of this, there hasn't been the need for things like the "blood donation trucks" etc. and maybe it hasn't gotten as much publicity because of it.  I think that more things should exist naturally in environments that just show people registering is a normal thing- like donating blood.

give_more_opportunities.title: Give more opportunities

targeting_hotels.description: Making kits available in hotel rooms will increase awareness, motivate people and earn them rewards.
targeting_hotels.creator: aaf0ecfa0d64e473caf39b0c4bc36096

comments.text: Nice idea Vishal! Hotels would be a great place to provide education and get people to swab their cheeks - all in the privacy of their hotel rooms!

targeting_hotels.title: Targeting Hotels

beyond_the_pat_on_the_back.description: RecycleBank has attracted over two million members to its recycling program. How? By rewarding them for their efforts.
beyond_the_pat_on_the_back.creator: 2fe9fbde5ee72e9fa725278585328741

comments.text: Yeah, I think they really nailed it. I'm curious to see if we could build on this as a concept.
I totally missed this when reading my first time around (so sorry) and just posted the same thing.  I think there's a ton to learn from RecycleBank.

beyond_the_pat_on_the_back.title: Beyond the Pat on the Back

sponsor_a_donee.description: This concept provides incentives to potential registrants by offering them the opportunity to know more about where their donation is going and who it is helping.
sponsor_a_donee.creator: db982e9fc3023ef8a7b620ec546f77d3
sponsor_a_donee.title: Sponsor a Donee

personal_connection.description: We spoke to a bone marrow recipient who was able to exchange letters with his donor. Though we didn't get to speak to the donor, no doubt this was helpful to him in agreeing to continue to donate, which he did three times for the same recipient.
personal_connection.creator: 7771fbb20af6ef10827c593daa3aff7b
personal_connection.title: Personal connection

the_biggest_rewardknowing_that_you_saved.description: Effective publicizing through TV commercials and other kinds of ads through social media featuring donors and patients.
the_biggest_rewardknowing_that_you_saved.creator: ca04790c3229cd292fac2224069a5ef6

comments.text: Good Idea Lily, I think that providing real-life testimonials in a PSA would make the issue more personal, and put a face on the problem at hand

the_biggest_rewardknowing_that_you_saved.title: The biggest reward=knowing that you saved a life

shop_swap_a_swab.description: Attractive tables in/around supermarkets (especially targeting under-represented populations, i.e. south asian groceries) swap a quick swab for a spin of the prize wheel which wins you: candy or entry into a raffle for a larger prize.  Make it clear that registering is non-binding and that there is a low chance of matching.  Emphasize prizes and fun.
shop_swap_a_swab.creator: 94f7404fc5aadd8a1b15326c1b8f61cd
shop_swap_a_swab.title: Shop Swap-a-Swab

tv_game.description: A game between celebrities recruiting as many donors as possible. The winner is the one who finds a donating match first. The donation is then televised if the donor agrees. The donor is celebrated as a hero and wins a day with the celebrity if the donor so choses.
tv_game.creator: 25c328e1221ccdc804d5c969f4124652

comments.text: Nice idea Joris. I could see something like this working on Celebrity Apprentice ( http://www.nbc.com/the-apprentice/ ,  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celebrity_Apprentice )

tv_game.title: TV game

three_fundamental_human_needs_insights_f.description: Borrowing insights from psychological research, how do we design a campaign that promotes three fundamental human needs?
three_fundamental_human_needs_insights_f.creator: 77136bfb5caf28c7790dcacea8c33612
three_fundamental_human_needs_insights_f.title: Three fundamental human needs -- insights from research in psychology

helpvinay_curesonia_curerayan_harnessing.description: Organizations like HelpVinay and CureSonia have increased the number of South Asians in the donor registry with a very short turnaround time -- a lot of this is due to the fact that they have effectively used the Internet and social media.
helpvinay_curesonia_curerayan_harnessing.creator: 5985a2173f02d421f866c74433afbb2c

comments.text: Cool idea Priya. Sort of like a Facebook Causes for marrow donors.

helpvinay_curesonia_curerayan_harnessing.title: HelpVinay, CureSonia, CureRayan - harnessing the power of social media

do1thing_for_life.creator: 2fd95a5594ba5fece5ba23b26b724839
do1thing_for_life.title: Do1Thing for Life

be_a_star.description: Create a series of videos or commercials starring registered bone marrow donors.  The only requirement to take part is that you've signed up to donate.  By offering individuals their own moment of fame, you encourage them to be part of the movement.
be_a_star.creator: b22c8efc945511851a0f7098f6bd753e

comments.text: Great idea. I was thinking along the same lines, and then started browsing the inspirations to find this one. This can also help in overcoming cultural challenges. What better way to convince people than to let them hear from their peers?

be_a_star.title: Be a star!

cricket_star_ads_to_encourage_south_asia.description: South Asians have  a particularly difficult time finding a match with low numbers of registered donors. But they are crazy about cricket in South Asia (India, Paklstan and Srilanka.) Cricket star based ads sell here. Let's spread awareness and motivate with cricket stars like Sachin Tendulkar.
cricket_star_ads_to_encourage_south_asia.creator: 2c93c685c88ffd584a20ad5a7749c509

comments.text: Witnessing the euphoria on the streets, in the newspapers, in conversations with people, on the TV, after India won the world cup, I belive if people like Yuvraj, Dhoni and Sachin appear in a bone marrow donation campaign, this will result in a tremendous wave of awareness and registration amongst Indians. Great concept! *applaud*
Love it. Make it competitive and it might really take off. India versus Pakistan Bone Marrow Registration Drive, all in good fun of course.

The idea is good . This drive should follow some awareness campaigns as the major reason behind low percentage of people donating bone marrows in south asian countries is ignorance. So, we need to educate them about the cause in detail through videos, pamphlets, tv ads and then pull in some celebrity or india-pakistan match to attract large crowds.
Same as the concept I posted :)http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-number-of-bone-marrow-donors-to-help-save-more-lives/concepting/cricket-and-the-promotion-campaign/
@ Kartik: Heh heh. The comment about India vs. Pakistan registration "fun competition" drive is pure genius. This would really, really work! :-)

cricket_star_ads_to_encourage_south_asia.title: Cricket Star ads to encourage South Asian donors

py/tuple: How easy is this concept to implement?
I could start right now.
This might take a bit of planning and probably some help from several partners.
This is a big undertaking and I'd need a lot of help from friends, organizations and other groups to make it happen.
Will this concept successfully reach and encourage under-represented populations (including South Asians) to join the bone marrow registry?
Yes, this concept will resonate with diverse groups of people from all over the world.
No, this concept might not reach under-represented populations very well.
I'm not sure, but I hope so!
How well does this concept dispel myths, ease fears, or provide education about bone marrow registration and donation?
Really well -- I already feel like I have a better understanding of the process and why it's important.
Okay, though it'll still take some explaining to get people to understand how bone marrow registration and donation work.
Not very well -- we'd have to create a highly detailed plan around this concept to help people understand.
How scalable is this concept?
This concept is highly scalable and could easily impact people all over the world.
This concept is really best suited for small groups and local areas.
This concept could be scaled, but we'd have to refine it for different settings.

utilizing_the_power_of_student_clubs.description: What if we reached out to diverse student clubs, especially South-Asian associations, on campuses throughout the country to help increase the number of registered donors?
utilizing_the_power_of_student_clubs.creator: 782b7ce25247ac9aac16f1675d70e4cf
utilizing_the_power_of_student_clubs.title: Utilizing the power of student clubs

get_companies_to_push_swabbing_among_emp.description: Bone marrow donation campaigns could capitalize on the growing trend of workplace volunteering as part of large corporations' CSR strategies. Getting companies to sign on to bone marrow awareness and registration campaigns within the workplace could provide access to thousands of potential donors, who simultaneously have an incentive to participate (to earn volunteer "comp hours," or to meet volunteer requirements). Furthermore, companies could assist in the cost of registration and donation through funds allocated to such CSR activities.
get_companies_to_push_swabbing_among_emp.creator: c3d2c86ab5e9c451939ad3195d121d8e
get_companies_to_push_swabbing_among_emp.title: Get Companies to Push Employee Swabbing as CSR

like_online_dating.description:
I think it would be easier for people to donate if the say the real people that need help. That will create empathy and willingness to help.
A such system where you match people; and let them know each other is the online dating websites.
like_online_dating.creator: 0a5f046a9c43d7d99c0064ee05e9f9fc

comments.text: This is interesting. So the person in need would have a profile and be thus "humanized" to potential donors. But what would give the donors incentive to join the site and surf it? If they're not getting a date, what are they getting out of it?

like_online_dating.title: Like online dating

touch_screen_kiosks_in_hospital_lobbies.description: Persuasive technology can be used to optimize wait time in hospital lobbies by introducing touch screen kiosks that educate on bone marrow donation, the process, the need and the ease with which the registration process can be completed.
touch_screen_kiosks_in_hospital_lobbies.creator: 4d8166f787cec2bce3183b1f74aae8ed

comments.text: Pavan, persuasively designed content would be critical in designing conversions here.
Thank you Sarah, will look into how one may integrate the information about microscope!

I like it! Anybody who'd spent time in a typical Indian hospital lobby would see how germane this point is. A captive audience of potential donors, and all we have to do is tap into their empathy (never in short supply in a hospital atmosphere), and move fast and clean  to ensure as high a convesrsion as possible.
I like how you convert the wait time in a hospital lobby into a potentially fruitful activity.
Nice idea Pritika! Now they've also transformed microscopes into a 46" interactive touchscreen: http://ow.ly/4oaDi This could be added to your concept :)

touch_screen_kiosks_in_hospital_lobbies.title: Touch screen kiosks in hospital lobbies

music_for_marrow.description: Multifaceted concept:  (1) Benefit Concert for Cancer Research and Bone Marrow Registration Drive, (2) Monetary Incentives on Music Download Sites like iTunes (and/or non music subscription sites like Netflix, etc.), and (3) Musical Media Commercial Campaign to Raise Awareness.  Read full description for details of each.
music_for_marrow.creator: a1e991dcff2a10a49b8e765d1ea4a0ee

comments.text: This is a great idea!! Building on point 2) Music for Marrow, maybe to incentivize people going thorugh with the donation once they are a match companies could offer free lifetime Itune downloads or free front row concert tickets that they fly you to no matter where you are!  They do promotional prizes like that already so it probably wouldnt be a huge additional cost either. (untill everyone starts swabbing and going through with the donation which is a great problem to have :) )

Jordan, I think it is a very good concept and I like the way you go from thinking big to thinking HUGE. However, as someone living outside the US, I think it would be great if it could be internationalized. An effort like Live8 (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Live_8) could be an example. With concerts on different continents, also to cross cultural barriers that might exist.Building further on your concept, it could be nice that people that register in the period up to the concert, or are already registered, can get a big discount on tickets for the concerts.One of the things that I think worked at the Hope for Haiti concert, was that a cd was available for download afterwards with recordings from the concert at full price. I believe that proceeds were going to the relief fund. It is, in my opinion, a good way to raise extra funds. People who were there will like it as a memento, and people who couldn't be at a concert would like it as a way to donate and get some great music in return.And again with the international view: it could be good to have some sort of dedicated website, where people could go to, select where they live and then get directed to their national bone marrow registration organisation. That would be in any case a good thing to have, so I will add that later as a separate concept.

music_for_marrow.title: Music for Marrow

make_it_a_game.description:
Apply a gaming framework to the act of marrow registration... Gaining registrations can become the task of an optimistic and blissfully productive workforce that is motivated by the opportunity to reach a personal epic achievement or accomplishment. 

The key is to tie the act of registering marrow donors to a gaming framework
make_it_a_game.creator: d4d3cbcf2b56f86cda6ce391aae8863a
make_it_a_game.title: Make it a Game

uncle_sam_wants_your_marrow.description: Building off the concept of asking the right people, brave and heroic members of the armed forces might be more receptive to the idea of donating.  Plus, with the system of built in medical history and diligent records, much of the work is already done.  This can also be applied to armed forces worldwide (the Uncle Sam title is just a sample campaign).
uncle_sam_wants_your_marrow.creator: a1e991dcff2a10a49b8e765d1ea4a0ee

comments.text: Great idea Jordan.  Woke up this morning with the same thought.

Jordan, you're really on a roll with your marrow donor concepts!  Recognizing the heroic nature soldiers, the influence of officers, and competitive spirit to increase donations...makes a lot of sense.

uncle_sam_wants_your_marrow.title: Uncle Sam Wants Your Marrow

3_day_for_the_cure_breast_cancer_walk.description: I just signed up for a 60 mile, 3 day walk for breast cancer and committed to raise $2,300 by September!
3_day_for_the_cure_breast_cancer_walk.creator: 24f6e3dc1bbc5a5dfb1e5c6481b94eb7

comments.text: Compelling personal account Liz  what a brilliant way to honour your mother.
Thanks for sharing this Liz - what a wonderful tribute.

3_day_for_the_cure_breast_cancer_walk.title: 3-day for the Cure breast cancer walk

tap_into_the_influence_of_spiritual_lead.description:
We all know donating bone marrows saves lives, simple as that. No spiritual leaders and faith organizations can deny the importance of a great cause such as saving lives. 
How can we provide the right resources to spiritual leaders and faith organizations who often have great influence over their congregation, so they can can effectively partner with bone marrow agencies to increase the bone marrow registries?
tap_into_the_influence_of_spiritual_lead.creator: 59054561fe9b4dddd6fbec03ad0d1184

comments.text: Great thinking Chloe! There will always, in every religion, be fundamentalistic extremists that find this ungodly, but I think most will find this a very valuable concept. And it plays very well to the community role spiritual leaders fulfill. I myself might not be a religious person, but I greatly value spiritual leaders that take responsibility for their flocks. And I love that you not only put this concept up on this platform, but also put it into practice by going to your pastor with it. Applause and respect!
Arjan, thank you! And congrats to your great concept too on Be The International Match!

Great concept Chloe,There is verse in Quran that says:  .... whoever kills a soul unless for a soul or for corruption [done] in the land - it is as if he had slain mankind entirely. And whoever saves one - it is as if he had saved mankind entirely. .... 5:32 As you mentioned religious leaders can support this movement and as much as I know, most of religions encouraging saving lives. It's very proper and nice idea to link this human-saving social activity to deep religious thinking and living.
Mohammad, thank you so much for your comment and sharing. And thanks for your great inspiration that sparks me on this concept! :)
This idea is of great value, as religious leaders have great power and could motivate many followers.

Great idea this is targeting exactly the type of market that would want to be part of the solution. Bring the the stations to the actual places of worship would eliminate one of the biggest barriers to being tested. Lots of potential here if religious institutions are open to the idea.

Chloe, excellent concept. I love the grass roots approach--it really leverages the power of community and trusted relationships to raise awareness and recruit volunteers from diverse groups everywhere. As your maps show, churches are ubiquitous! Another aspect I like about your concept is that spiritual communities provide a built-in support network for a volunteer who is actually called in to donate! Well done.
Agree with your comments, Vincent. I often forget how powerful religion is, especially when you reach out to all religions - a leading by example method would work really well.

Religion is a powerful motivating force that spans across diverse communities.  You've really moved things forward by mapping out the details and then actually approaching your pastor about implementation!

tap_into_the_influence_of_spiritual_lead.title: Tap into the Influence of Spiritual Leaders

pink_ribbons_for_breast_cancer.description: The Pink Ribbon has become a universal symbol and fashion statement for breast cancer. Can we create a similar symbol for bone marrow? Can it be wearable or visible in daily life?
pink_ribbons_for_breast_cancer.creator: e271b7c6ed709feca8776fd4f9b91e86

comments.text: I'm surprised no one posted inspiration from Movember, the prostate cancer charity! That is such an amazing awareness raising fund raiser. seeing lots of men with moustaches gets everyone talking and makes men feel proud to be part of it - solidarity!

To use pride of being a donor it should be something cool and immediately visible to others. We should create some fashionable item that you want to wear often and give it only to people who donated so everybody can see that they care about others. But because people don't always want to be a show off, we can tell them it is to encourage others to become a donor. This has a dual function; you increase exposure of the cause and you increase the desirability of being a donor.
Great thinking, Haiyan.  How could we make private decisions public, in order to build awareness and encourage action?

pink_ribbons_for_breast_cancer.title: Pink ribbons for breast cancer

project_michelle_and_aadp.description: Project Michelle was a friend and family led campaign that registered over 18,000 potential donors and passed a Senate Bill in CA for paid time off for marrow donation!

project_michelle_and_aadp.title: Project Michelle and AADP

sponsor_me_with_a_swab.description: Instead of having friends and family sponsor you to do an activity for money, have them pledge to register on the bone marrow database if you complete your task.
sponsor_me_with_a_swab.creator: 8fac924254004c7d9240333ca42693c5

comments.text: This is awesome! I like the idea of putting a person who is 'running for a cause' at the helm of an action oriented campaign! Many marathons these days make it easy for someone to set up a fundraising webpage, but what if this were coupled with a 'testing kit'. Registration includes: webpage, testing kit, bib etc.On a website, a runner could track and promote collections, donations, and highlight the people around them who have signed up to register. Simultaneously, this would provide the person fundraising with tangible interactions in their community to help raise awareness about the need for increased bone marrow registrations.
This is so simple and excellent. I find it hard asking people for money for sponsoring runs I do but asking for a swab would be so much easier!
This is so simple and excellent. I find it hard asking people for money for sponsoring runs I do but asking for a swab would be so much easier!

Like the previous commenters, I like how this take a conversation from $$ to attention.  Attention is something we can all give, and its great to reinforce the idea that you can have an impact without having to break open your wallet.

Wonderful idea. I think this whole registering and possibly saving a life as a way to donate to a cause or charity, could be a great way to look at it. Like Nancy said, it's perfect for the hard times some are going through. I think this idea of registering as charity could be taken in many directions as well. There are plenty of opportunities where people are willing to help charities.
Thanks Vincent, Thanks Nancy.

I like this idea mainly because not everyone has the money these days to give to charity eventhough they would like to help the cause.  Having people sign up in place/in addition to giving money is a great way to make people feel like they have more choices in ways to contribute.

I like this idea mainly because not everyone has the money these days to give to charity eventhough they would like to help the cause.  Having people sign up in place/in addition to giving money is a great way to make people feel like they have more choices in ways to contribute.
Brilliant change up from the typical pledge ask.

sponsor_me_with_a_swab.title: Sponsor me with a swab!

learn_from_thon.description: Penn State's Dance Marathon (happening today!) is the largest student-run philanthropy in the world. They involve 15,000 students each year and since 1973 have raised more than $69 million for childhood cancers. How do we do something like that?!?
learn_from_thon.creator: 5bbc287f5f1b93ebc407228c791f346c

comments.text: Katie, great idea to tap into the energy of dance marathon! This got me thinking...if we made a focused effort even to do drives at these types of student events, where people are already there because they want to make a difference, we could create a lot of awareness and participation for the cause. I hadn't heard of the hackathon, how cool!

gain_fans_through_church_fans.description: Taking advantage of a captive, spiritual audience, promote becoming a bone marrow donor on church fans and pass them out at services for free.

comments.text: I think this could really work in certain communities.  I was a missionary in Sacramento and we had several church congregations that were predominantly Southeast Asian based.  As with any church, they were constantly looking for ways to help.  I think it would be as simple as pitching the concept to the leadership of the congregation.  Perhaps combine it with another service activity, say a blood drive?

gain_fans_through_church_fans.title: Gain Fans Through (Church) Fans

youtube_interactive_walk_through_the_pro.description: A simple concept incorporated into a wider promotional / awareness campaign might include a "choose your adventure" type Youtube video that is interactive. Yes, Youtube has interactive elements like hyperlinks to other videos within the video itself (for example: check the basics of how it works in the attached video). You could create short clips of the process from various perspectives: (a) the potential donor and (b) the recipient -- both branching out to different scenarios.
youtube_interactive_walk_through_the_pro.creator: 3477f2719c2ec13566dddb41787b8089

comments.text: Thanks for this Sina. I've used your concept to build on my http://bit.ly/e21eZF previous concept.
I saw... and really like it!

I love the idea of choosing your own adventure! Great idea Sina. And to your other point, stay tuned in the coming weeks - we're working on some exciting developments that'll hopefully make commenting more fun and interactive :)
Ashely... OpenIDEO has gone INCEPTION on us.. applaud an applaud an applaud

This is a great way to unpack the process and really 'show' people how easy registration and donation can be. py/tuple: How easy is this concept to implement?
I could start right now.
This might take a bit of planning and probably some help from several partners.
This is a big undertaking and I'd need a lot of help from friends, organizations and other groups to make it happen.
Will this concept successfully reach and encourage under-represented populations (including South Asians) to join the bone marrow registry?
Yes, this concept will resonate with diverse groups of people from all over the world.
No, this concept might not reach under-represented populations very well.
I'm not sure, but I hope so!
How well does this concept dispel myths, ease fears, or provide education about bone marrow registration and donation?
Really well -- I already feel like I have a better understanding of the process and why it's important.
Okay, though it'll still take some explaining to get people to understand how bone marrow registration and donation work.
Not very well -- we'd have to create a highly detailed plan around this concept to help people understand.
How scalable is this concept?
This concept is highly scalable and could easily impact people all over the world.
This concept is really best suited for small groups and local areas.
This concept could be scaled, but we'd have to refine it for different settings.

lifelong_branding.description: Longitudinal exposure to branded ideas increases the persuasive power of the message. This idea seeks to expose and educate bone marrow donation as normative and preferred behavior by increasing messaging touchpoints. For example, having a square/community card on the board games "Life" and "Monopoly" (respectively) that states you donated bone marrow and received a citizenship award, or educating high school students about the donation process as part of their regular health class discussion on interpersonal disease prevention. By taking a longitudinal approach (much like other campaigns such as being "green" and anti-smoking), the likelihood of sustainable, long-term, societal change regarding donation increases.
lifelong_branding.creator: 81bdd23f02be16953b223fbb3f523b62
lifelong_branding.title: Lifelong branding

Maybe it's time to take on this secrecy/privacy issue, and create a transparent network of those in need and those in abundance.

marrow_miner_invention.description: Great video on TED.com of Dr. Daniel Kraft's invention. Harvesting can be done with one puncture and local anesthetic as an out patient with his Marrow Miner invention.
marrow_miner_invention.creator: fd78d10f2bffc2328cbed014252099b6

comments.text: I don't do Bone Marrow transplant due to the pain and operation involved if I am a match. With this device I could overcome the level of pain involved (local) to become a donor.  How can you find a place that uses this equipment and procedure?

My daughter has stage 4 Neuroblastoma. I was wondering if the marrow miner has only been used to collect bone marrow from donors or if it has been used to collect marrow to harvest stem cells for an Autologous Stem Cell Transplant? The Periphial Blood Harvest is not an option for her. HELP PLEASE!!!!!!

Hi Aubree, cheers for checking out our challenge - it's clear it hits close to home for you. Unfortunately the Marrow Miner is just an inspiration that Michelle shared with our community to learn more; it's not something she created herself. It's probably best to consult with your daughter's physician and explore your questions with their help. We wish you and your daughter the best, thanks again for getting in touch.Ashley (OpenIDEO community manager)
Wow, this is such a great innovation.  I think more people will be will be likely to donate when they find out the procedure is less invasive and easier than they thought.

Ashley--Thanks for posting the actual video from YouTube.  Chloe - It will be interesting to watch the distribution of this product and whether it is adopted quickly by doctors. Money always comes to mind for me as a motivator for hospitals in changing procedures:  outpatient procedure vs. a stay in the hospital; local anesthetic vs. general anesthetic.  But how to get them to more readily adopt innovative design is definitely an intriguing question.

Hi Michelle, thank you for sharing this. If this technology is more widely implemented, it can definitely help reduce the emotional hurdle of donating when people are deciding to sign up. From Daniel's wiki page (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Kraft), it seems that the device has now being commercialized by Hospira Inc. for use in bone marrow transplantation and by RegenMed Systems for use in regenerative medicine, but not much information can be found on its distribution. Adopting a new way to doing medical procedure often takes time and more up front cost, but the benefit is immense. How can we change the mentality of the health care industry (hospitals, private doctors, etc) so they can adopt innovative design like this in a quicker pace which will in turn increase the number of registered bone marrow donors?

HI Michelle, what a fascinating invention the Marrow Miner is! It looked like you might have had some trouble uploading the TED talk so I went ahead and found a clip of Daniel Kraft's talk on YouTube to add to your Inspiration. Great find!

Daniel: One thing I've learned is that the method of extraction is dictated by the recipient's physician, and that because of privacy concerns this information is not supplied until late in the game.  Therefore, when you are a match, and you get called up to see if you will in fact donate, they must inform you of the worst case scenario, which is that you could be asked to donate marrow (a surgical procedure under anesthesia), see it here:  http://www.marrow.org/DONOR/When_You_re_Asked_to_Donate_fo/Steps_of_Donation/marrow.htmlSo, anecdotally, many people aren't prepared for that level of potential commitment, it comes as a surprise, and they back out.

Inspiration 27 (of current 36) is titled "Does It Hurt?" and has a link to a video of some street interviews with people who have/had the reaction of fear of the pain.  It's anecdotal information, but gives some indication.
I'd like to know if the fear of the donation pain is a significant influence on the number of bone marrow donors. Do we have this information?

Very cool! Especially when he refers to how this new device/procedure only requires 1 hole, vs. repeating a process/"swiss cheesing" the donor's bone many times. At the same time, to be honest, the animation showing the amount of marrow being sucked out is a bit frightening to me.

I somehow deleted this info when I posted the TED description, but marrow harvesting with the Marrow Miner is done with only one puncture and a local anesthetic, and is performed as an outpatient procedure.

marrow_miner_invention.title: Marrow Miner invention

comments.text: Hi Vincent, Thanks for your comment. I was also worried about the monetary cost that Nat Geo would be willing to take on. However, it may be possible that the the promotional and good-will benefits to the company could offset their costs. If this were not the case, perhaps another group of publicly funded genetic researchers would be additionally happy to partner with Nat Geo and 100K Cheeks to add to their own studies while paying for some of the costs out of their research budgets.

Hi Kevin, Thanks for your feedback! I really like your idea of Nat Geo tapping into their current group of already genetically-interested users! We could design a whole campaign about them reaching out in a way that says, you've found out about your ancestors and the legacy that they have left you, now leave your own legacy by saving a life! Register to be a bone marrow donor today.

I really like this idea Amanda. Building on what Vincent alluded to, 100K Cheek can also work with Nat Geo to send out consent forms to people who have already submitted their cheek swab samples to obtain their consent to further analyze the samples to type their genotypes. This will be at no cost to the public who have already paid for the kit and only minor additional costs to reanalyze the sample.

Interesting idea Amanda. Although I think it might be difficult to make the $100 National Geographic fee completely free for marrow registrations (since National Geographic is already using this as a funding mechanism for research, education, cultural conservation, & language revitalization efforts), it seems like an easy minimal cost add for them to put a bone marrow donor opt-in into their registration process that already requires cheek swabs.

linking_annual_physical_blood_donation_m.description:
How many of you have experienced the discomfort of a blood test? I've often thought, "If I need to feel a little pain anyways, why not just leave the needle in longer & donate some blood too?"

Consider that much of the blood donation process overlaps with your regular physical checkup/lab test: sign-in registration, waiting, vitals check (temp, pulse, blood pressure, etc.), interview, bandage, & relief that it's over! In addition, this may naturally match donation supply & demand to a degree, lowering distribution costs, as larger hospitals with more recipient needs are also likely to have a larger pool of checkup blood tests/potential donors.

Marrow donor registration could also piggyback here, as the initial testing process can be done using drawn blood or cheek swabs. And for people who've already donated blood, the typical PBSC marrow donation (of cells circulating in the blood) is not all that different, so completion of rates of those following through on matched donations should be high.
linking_annual_physical_blood_donation_m.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Check out this new related product launch, debuting at TED, that  Bundles Bandaids with Bone Marrow Registration! http://www.fastcoexist.com/1679387/a-bandage-that-allows-you-to-save-a-life-while-patching-up-your-cut
Thanks everyone for the support & feedback! Will try to update this concept based on your builds if it makes it through to the next phase.

These types of things could be nice ways as well to minimize the perceived wait time in the doctor's office. I visited a really cool diabetes center in Abu Dhabi and the whole flow was set up so that the patient was "busy" - e.g., getting blood drawn, BP check, etc while "waiting" for the doctor. What else could we add in to make the wait go away?

This is a great idea - because of it's possibility for scale and replication. It certainly makes sense to collect blood donations and blood marrow at the same time because of the doctors have all the resources and are there continuously (vs. drives or booths only around for a short period of time). There are also things you can learn about your health when giving blood (e.g. if you're anemic, or have HIV ). The doctor would be able to address those issues at the same time.I am curious how the concept of lowering copayment/checkup fees will affect low-income communities. On the one hand, it could encourage regular checkups in for certain people. On the other hand, it could also seem as if they are "selling" their blood in exchange for doctors' fees.

Great idea. The utilization of the most trustworthy communication channel to convey the message increases the possibility for the message to be received. This puts pressure on the health professional on what things/causes they promote and support. On the other hand, this is also a way for the doctors/dentists to express their values and sense of community.

I like the idea of grouping all of these things together, mainly because your doctor is a very good source of information and can fill in any gaps or concerns you might have.  I would feel much more comfortable having the doctor explain to me the process instead of a random person at an information booth.  The only downside that I see here is that some people might feel like their doctor is putting them on the spot if they are asked then & there to donate blood or sign up for the bone marrow registery.  Although I trust my doctor for information, I'd feel pressured to sign up if he/she is standing right there.  Doctors can be effective influencers and maybe they can at least suggest/promote the option of signing up at the front desk when the patient leaves.
This is a real interesting idea- it could also be offered by dentists who are seen more regularly and are already digging around in our mouths.

Really interesting idea about having the patient's insurance compensate you in some way for donating (free health insurance for some time, for example).  That could definitely encourage even those without adequate access to regular health care to be part of the registry.

linking_annual_physical_blood_donation_m.title: Linking Annual Physical, Blood Donation, & Marrow Registration

comments.text: I love where this conversation is headed - if we're going to raise awareness, and we want do it for all age groups/demographics, we need to think about the best way to dialogue with and educate each generation in its own way. Great job all.

Louise - I just checked out your Lisa Simpson concept and totally agree. I like the idea of building strong and important messaging into the programs people watch. The Simpsons is a great idea because it is known not just for being funny, but for thoughtful humor. (If you get a chance you should check out the Banksy episode).In terms of building, I like the idea of targeting those programs that have the potential to make people really think/reflect across different age groups. Sesame Street is obviously for young viewers. The Simpsons takes you from adolescence to adulthood. What other steps in the ladder can we penetrate?

I like your comment about how children take the idea to their parents once they've watched episodes that inspire them!What do you think of my Simpson's concept, using  Lisa Simpson to story tell about bone marrow donation? Similar ideas to build on?

Thanks Larry! I like your thinking. While I was considering this as a more media/education concept in order to ripple influence out toward parents.......maybe this can be tied to physical screening in other areas where children like to play and learn. Sesame street branded swab kits? Available in play gyms, preschools, etc?
Neat concept!   Since your bone marrow typing doesn't change over time, there's no reason not to get someone in the database ASAP.
