comments.text: Connects with the audience instantly.
Nothing like seeing it first hand. No better way to take the wind out of the sails of fear.

Right on! The challenge is how to add a little warmth to it to personalize the donation experience. Some of my best medical experiences occur when the doctors recognize my humanity and feelings, positive or negative, rather than just see me as another specimen. I guess they refer to that as "the bedside manner."

and_now_for_real_life....title: And now for real life...

make_it_personal.description: Let's make it easy to see people need of matches, to bring it to life for donors.
make_it_personal.creator: 7771fbb20af6ef10827c593daa3aff7b

comments.text: This reminds me of the MarrowMe concept (http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-number-of-bone-marrow-donors-to-help-save-more-lives/concepting/marrow-me-registry/). I said it reminded me of a Kiva.org for marrow donors...this would be a good combination with that idea I think.
Personalising an appeal is certainly the surest way of getting help when it's needed. There's something about the institutionalising of the appeal that removes its ability to tug at the heartstrings.

make_it_personal.title: Make it personal

encourage_south_asian_celebrities_to_pro.description:
Kal Penn. Padma Lakshmi. Naeem Khan. Mira Nair.

These are all people who have a vast amount of influence, both offline and through social media. Let's inspire these people to encourage bone marrow donations.
encourage_south_asian_celebrities_to_pro.creator: a46ad8b543de3b307685920dd10525e4

comments.text: See if cheek swab and the need for South Asians in the registry can be worked into the plot line of an episode for a hit TV show.  Bones?  House?  Reach out to Stanford Alumni in Entertainment and pitch this to writers.

Marrow Donor Registry India (https://www.mdrindia.org, http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=122781516547) is a registry that was started in Mumbai, and has partnered with actor Salman Khan to promote their cause--I believe he was their first registrant. Despite that, the overall response to the registry has been low due to some of the other issues people have raised here. I agree with you that a celebrity endorsement is a great idea to make people aware of the problem and bring them to the table, especially in the South Asian community, given the enormous popularity celebrities have. However, the critical next step is to provide a forum for all of the people "at the table" to then collaborate and contribute ideas in a way that makes them feel some level of ownership of the problem--and that is what will bring change.
As a South Asian, I can definitely see something like this having legs!

encourage_south_asian_celebrities_to_pro.title: Encourage South Asian Celebrities to Promote Bone Marrow Registration and Donation

find_the_places_where_people_have_time.description: By finding places where people have the time to be introduced to new things, people will be educated, more interested in helping and spreading the word around.
find_the_places_where_people_have_time.creator: ca71b55cf4461fbb9c78f72b34303266

comments.text: Often well-intentioned actions like these go wrong as we exaggerate the rational aspects of peoples behavior. To simplify: we are more driven by other peoples behavior and convenience than we are by going through pros and cons.Just as an example: no one has actually never asked me to take the sample. The essential thing is giving the information together with the opportunity to act.How long does taking the sample actually take? Not long, I presum. Therefore the emphasis needs to be put on analysing where people would have the moment to give the sample but also have the possibility for a more elaborate discussion taking away the worries.Good interventions I can think of:- airports and train stations- personnel restaurants'- NGOs- parents watching basketball games or ballet classes of their kids- theatres and orchestrasAnd essential thing is also giving people the story to take home. I mean showing the effect donation can have on someones life. This can be through a video but even better from a real person. I mean the best thing would be that a story of the impact would be told around the dinner table and the person telling it would also have the information on possibilities for the others to donate.
I love the idea of finding moments when it's more likely (/convenient) for people to give!
I love the idea of finding moments when it's more likely (/convenient) for people to give!

find_the_places_where_people_have_time.title: Find the places where people have time

pay_donors_in_3rd_world_countries_with_u.description: Certain populations are under-represented in existing bone marrow registries.  The majority of these populations are in countries with relatively low incomes.  Pay donors in these countries a small amount to register and a larger amount to donate.
pay_donors_in_3rd_world_countries_with_u.creator: 8ccfcb411cec66a9aef99faf1b43af18

comments.text: I would encourage that you expand this to also include people from the developed world. A small amount of money, or a gift card as a thank you, is not unprecedented. Blood banks give you cookies after you donate blood...you might get more interest if that same blood bank handed out the monetary value of those cookies ($2).Veronica, your point is a good one. My creating the market, you are legitimizing the trade. That said, in some cases, a regulated legitimate market is often better for all involved than an unregulated black market for those same goods.My concern regarding using 3rd world countries is that their bone marrow will be primarily benefiting the rich urban elite. If I live off the grid in a poor village in SE Asia, and I have cancer, even if my mother donates bone marrow, I will never have the means for a transplant.That said, based on my experience in rural Cambodia, I believe that the cost to register could be much, much lower. For a simple cheek swab, people would be lining up for the equivalent of 12 cents.

I love this idea because it 1) could reach the populations whose registration is most needed, and 2) because it connects people internationally for a common cause.  However, I can't stop the business half of me from wondering how to pay for it?

@Krassimira, thanks for your observation, it's a difficult topic. Anyways, I think is the same case as people selling their children. Same as in Argentina where I come from. Young women are kidnapped and force to prostitute themselves in order to give money to someone who is in charge. Theses are examples of unofficial markets. But If you create the market you are allowing this things to happen.Giving money neither will change people's attitude towards donation, nor will put a population in a better situation.This is my opinion based on my ideals and values, it doesn't mean that I'm right.Interesting debate!

Matthew, I believe you're bringing a great point. @Veronica: In the country where I come from, Bulgaria, and in the neighbouring country, Romania, the folks from the Roma community (a subgroup that populates Central and Eastern Europe) live in extreme poverty and it is not unusal that they sell their children for as low as 50$. If they are offered the possibility to register and donate blood/bone marrow and be given monetary incentives, they will definitley do so compared to other alternatives.

Matthew, thanks for your post. The question of how we can incentivize people to sign up to donate is a common and very important one. We encourage you to hold on to this for the Concepting phase as it's really a potential solution we should all explore together.Veronica, your comment raises some good questions too, and clearly there's a need for some more discussion during Concepting. In the meantime, are there examples of existing campaigns or programs that have successfully gotten people from all walks of life to register as donors? The Inspiration phase is a great time for research - and we'll be excited to hear what everyone comes up with.

Im concern about this inspirational concept. This idea reveals how  3rd world countries had suffered (and suffer) from the abuse of power of 1st world countries by showing a little bit of money or just more intimidatory ways. This countries need a change no your pocket change. Where does their donation go? Is it for them? To help themselves? Im pretty sure it doesnt.Secondly I think this author does not know how people live and work in those places. I think is not correct the assumption that paying people for taking a couple of days off will make them go for it.Lastly, I think the author should be more informed about behavioral change. Giving a reward doesnt make a true change.Sorry if Im to critical.

pay_donors_in_3rd_world_countries_with_u.title: Pay donors in 3rd world countries with under-represented populations to register and donate

make_good_use_of_people_who_are_caught_w.description: We have all been caught waiting for a physician. Either waiting for a check up in one of the doctor's rooms, or waiting in a hospital visit. In this time, you are usually waiting for a free doctor or some results and instead of looking around the blank white walls or examining some tools, you could be reading a few pages of information about joining the registry. You can make up your mind, and the doctor may even help with the swab when he returns.
make_good_use_of_people_who_are_caught_w.creator: 3b871ab65d3d7f47820f2a1eba626b5b
make_good_use_of_people_who_are_caught_w.title: Make Good Use of People Who are Caught Waiting

assuaging_african_american_fears_through.description: I propose instituting a church or other faith-based partnership with local hospitals and donation centers that would task the clergymen to raise awareness, educate, and sign up African-American members (and other ethnicities) to donate.
assuaging_african_american_fears_through.creator: 0ee90c8e96034d59dd7f83e65d851dd4

comments.text: You hit the nail right on the head with this one. My father grew up in the Deep South and was so wary of medical professionals and institutions that it was 30 years before he finally saw a doctor, and it was not by choice. The church has been one the few sites of trust for the black community and I think it is great that you are thinking about how to leverage such a cornerstone. An additional potential obstacle is the possible belief within the black community that they are not prone to blood cancers or other illnesses requiring bone marrow. Too often the faces of these diseases are overwhelmingly white. If one does not see members of their community represented, one might assume that the issue, location, concern, etc. does not apply to their community. I suggest that congregations should be introduced to black patients and donors who can share their experiences and make it known that these diseases know no cultural bounds.

assuaging_african_american_fears_through.title: Assuaging African-American Fears Through Clergy-Based Education

get_bone_marrow_from_donors_getting_hip_.description: Could Bone Marrow be obtained from people have bones being replaced?
get_bone_marrow_from_donors_getting_hip_.creator: f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb

comments.text: Thank you for your comment.  Some of my confusion deals with how the registry is typically used.  I was thinking that there were recipients waiting for a donor, but the general case is probably donors waiting for a recipient.  Perhaps that is a misconception I have formed from hearing about drives to help particular individuals whoses ethnic background is poorly represented in the registry.My reason for submitting this is to address some of the issues listed here: http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-number-of-bone-marrow-donors-to-help-save-more-lives/barriers-to-bone-marrow-donation/Some of these barriers seem irrelevant, given they will have joint replacement surgery.My biggest concern was there was some medical reason that the replacement surgery process would make your donation at that time (or in the future) useless.  Blood donations have a long litany of deferment issues.  Are there similar ones for these stem cells?

This is not about the bone marrow, but about the hematopoetic stem cells in the bone marrow. It is very hard to find a suitable match for a recipient, and most registered donors are not matches for anyone. Hence preserving the bone marrow or extracting its stem cells (expensive processes) from each replaced hip just for the unlikely event that someone will need that exact HLA profile in the future seems unrealistic IMO.

get_bone_marrow_from_donors_getting_hip_.title: Get Bone Marrow from Donors getting Hip/Knee/Sholder Replacement

the_dmv_has_it_all_waiting_time_identity.description: Feel good in the crappiest place ever? Building on the "organ donors are sexy" inspiration and other early thoughts, I'm wondering if the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) might be an ideal setting to get people to swab. Register your marrow as your register your car! And, maybe even get an icon on your license that shows what a good person you are.
the_dmv_has_it_all_waiting_time_identity.creator: 68c03a76152dc53fdd2c7c7ab07f2721

comments.text: Interesting thought, William. Are you thinking something like a window or bumper STICKER? What about a BONE icon that can be part of your vanity plate (like hearts), only if you are a donor? Maybe a key chain or a special holder for your registration papers?
Great inspiration!I'd add a badge that can be showcased in the vehicle. If you ever become a donor an aditional badge could be given to the donor.

Cool Chris, was actually about to post something along similar lines. Have added as a build to your inspiration here:Hate waiting forever at the DMV (Department of Motor Vehicles)? What if when you are filling out your form for license renewal (which often includes opt-in organ donor option), you could also do a cheek swab on the spot to register as a bone marrow donor? If you do, not only would you get a cool bones badge on your license (perhaps swaying the nice officer who pulls you over for a traffic violation to let you off with a warning), but you also get put to the front of the line for getting your license.

the_dmv_has_it_all_waiting_time_identity.title: The DMV has it all: waiting time, identity, "sexy" donors

bones_for_freedom..description: Allow people who have taken from society to have a chance to give back and help others.
bones_for_freedom..creator: ee8d81b0b99491646ada097a4ab14fba

comments.text: Great idea. I did not see your concept and added something similar. I am not worried about the exploitation angle at all. It's opt in, not opt out. And once in the registry, the record remains, even after leaving prison.

I agree that this is an intriguing idea, though Ann raises an important concern. Prison populations at risk for exploitation, but with the proper organizations implementing the program and providing oversight, I think it can be very successful. Most prisoners are in jail for non-violent offenses (drugs, 3-strikes, B&E, theft, etc) and come from environments where empathy and helping others were not at the top of the priority list. Something like this would help them to develop these key interpersonal skills. I recently read an article about a prison in South Africa that allows prisoners to raise birds that will later be adopted. Caring for an animal not only calms them down but teaches them true selfless actions. To echo Anna's question, what is the ultimate goal of including prisoners? Will it be time off for good behavior or just one part of the total rehabilitation process?

Very interesting idea, though if not handled carefully and specifically, has the potential to go awry, exploited by different parties or misunderstood. Which criminal offenses would be allowed this pathway, I wonder? Would it function in a similar way as good behavior? Is there in ethical problem in asking incarcerated people to donate their bodies? Is it almost Swiftian? Is there something in the prison population that would make them typically  bad donor, healthwise? Intriguing...

bones_for_freedom..title: Bones for freedom.

comments.text: Definitely, why not use a bad/damaging thing in a good way. Unfortunately a lot of people still smoke which means the messages on cigarette packages are still read by a wide range of people! Good idea - thought provoking

cigarettes_offering_some_good.title: Cigarettes offering some good?

openideoing_openideo.description: Expand this openIDEO challenge into physical locations. Part of the brilliance of openIDEO is that it is a media campaign within itself. Participants become more aware of bone marrow donor registration simply by tackling the problem of bone marrow donor registration. Therefore, I propose expanding openIDEO by leveraging personal social networks in the physical space.
openideoing_openideo.creator: 81bdd23f02be16953b223fbb3f523b62

comments.text: Terrific to hear you're hosting a brainstorm Ryan! We'll be so excited to see what concepts you come up with. And of course you can feel free to use our Brainstorm in a Box toolkit - www.bit.ly.bmc-brainstorm. Happy OpenSTORMING :)
Hey Everyone,If your in Phoenix, AZ area, I'm running a couple brain storming sessions on this challenge at the Urban Beans Cafe On Sat, March 26th from 900 AM - 200PM. Hope to see you there.
Very good point! I agree on the media campaign in itself. I also love the idea to bring it to the physical park. You could also imagine having places where people can register. al
Excellent idea Ryan.  You're right, I've learned more about donating bone marrow from this exercise than I ever did before, including registering through Gift of Life years ago.
Ryan, you're so right....I also catch myselft talking to colleagues during lunch and forwarding links to the community challenges....

Hi Ryan, first - welcome to OpenIDEO, and congrats on a terrific idea! We're thrilled to hear you're taking the Bone Marrow Donation Challenge to your community - and we hope you'll report back to us on how it goes! Not sure if you've seen our Brainstorm in a Box toolkit yet? We created one for the Maternal Health + Mobile Technology Challenge and we'll be launching one specifically for this Challenge in the next few days. Stay tuned - and great work!

Good observation that OpenIDEO challenges are "a media campaign within itself"! I've definitely learned a lot more from participating in these challenges. Kudos to you and your friend for creating a physical presence for this challenge as well. Also, did you know that you can attach files directly to share when posting or updating (one of the buttons on the top-right) concepts?

openideoing_openideo.title: OpenIDEOing OpenIDEO

celebrate_hero_anniversaries_on_social_m.creator: 079a7f75cdf4ab84c43ac9d7da611348

comments.text: Awesome Virada! Anniversaries would be a great way to honor and spread the word. This could also be complemented by a viral component to ripple it out to the n-th degree: http://bit.ly/hHxeQX

become_a_champion.creator: f86beae605f264a32bdb17a8ff33118b

swab_spit_share.description: Dentists could register their patients to become bone marrow donors during appointments. Many people may fear sitting in the dentist's chair, but they could feel better if they felt they were helping others.
swab_spit_share.creator: 5d92f71f013327caa7da5bc8853c12de

comments.text: Love this idea, Jennifer S.Rather than a monetary reward for participation, what about social recognition?  Perhaps in the waiting room, have an "I got swabbed" thank you board that includes pictures of all the potential donors (digital or Polaroids taken on site), along with some educational materials.  If any of these folks become actual donors, create a special "we love our donor" display highlighting that person (including pics and a personal story if possible).  This could help overcome the fear barrier - wow, my neighbors are doing this - and is surely a more interesting use of their time than reading People magazine.  Several banks in my neighborhood have boards where they take/post pictures of all the dogs that come into the bank - it is surprising just how much traffic/attention those displays receive.
One other thought - to get the ball rolling, the first pictures up could be of the dentist and all of his/her staff.

Debbie, that's a great idea! It's very practical to implement, and creates positive reinforcement to register. If patients see that it's something many people are doing, they will be more likely to participate. When I asked the teller at the local DMV how many people she had registered to become organ donors, she said had no idea, and that she hadnt thought about it before.

As others have mentioned, this concept provides a brilliant use of the patient's time while they're reclining agape.  I've also often wished for dentists to provide something mentally engaging on the ceiling to watch while I'm reclining and am fairly useless as a patient.  The dentist's ceiling above the patient could be used to display priming incentives and/or an educational campaign (e.g., examples of patients in need of donors, information about the donation process, etc.).

This is a great idea because of how little participation it takes from the potential donor. We are all compassionate and perform small acts of humanity everyday, but they're mostly those which present themselves to us in our daily routine: holding the door open for someone; offering an elderly person your seat on the train. By proffering a swab to people who are already seated and agape, the dentist is simply offering the patient a chance to perform a painless act of decency.Top idea!

Perfect registration opportunity.  Plus since the dentist does most of the talking when you are in the chair, he or she could educate their patient about how important bone marrow testing is.  Best of all the lecture is coming from a respected MD.   Brilliant!

When I first read the challenge the first thing I thought of was why not get asked to register when you get asked to become an organ-donor for license renewal or registry but this concept takes away an extra step that one would have to take  after agreeing to register, going to a health center to get swabbed. If my dentist educated me slightly, asked me to register and offered to swab me during my next appointment, I certainly would and I know many family and friends that would too!
Absolute genius. So easy to implement, since there is very little convincing one needs to do.The dentist is taking your cheek swab whether you like it or not!
Just noticed this and love the idea! Really holds possibility for making it easier to access the tests.

It would be nice to incorporate staff that aren't dentists into this process. I know I spend a lot of time waiting around, in the waiting room and dentist chair. Perhaps dental assistants or office staff could be blood marrow reps and visit with patients while they're waiting!

Susan and Bo,Great feedback-thank you!You're right. It would be helpful to add in an incentive to get users to sign up, and to encourage them to donate if they ever get called. I'm struggling to determine a feasible/stretch-incentive to share with users who become donors. A lifetime of free insurance or dental services could be a a great incentive for donors. Given the large volume of potential donors we'd like to acquire, am curious if we could build a cost-benefit model that creates an incentive that could be feasibly funded. What are your thoughts or recommendations?

Well done on combining a few really important elements in the concept! You have the captive audience to hear about the importance of registering, the fact that they're hearing the details from a trained and (hopefully) trusted medical professional and they're already mentally prepared for proceedures involving their mouth. Great multi-barrier addressing! I think the idea of an added incentive would be great, and I'm wondering if this could be expanded? Say that a person who registers gets 20% off their next visit - if they are asked to donate could they get free lifetime dental care? Simulating could you incentivise the dentist to participate by rewarding them with discounted insurance/lower taxes/VAT less equipment buying? Just some ideas, well done on a great concept!

great idea! i think the key might be to provide strong incentives by placing either intrinsic reward (make the experience very, very satisfying for donors e.g. emphasize how valuable their registration is, for example by giving them examples of patients in need who successfully got bone marrow transplant) or extrinsic reward (e.g. financial incentives if this is possible at all -- swab your cheek and get 20% off the cost of your dental visit)
What a great idea! Patients in the dental chair are already mentally primed to open their mouths and say "Ahhhh"... seems like a golden opportunity to take a sample.

swab_spit_share.title: Swab, Spit & Share

py/tuple: How easy is this concept to implement?
I could start right now.
This might take a bit of planning and probably some help from several partners.
This is a big undertaking and I'd need a lot of help from friends, organizations and other groups to make it happen.
Will this concept successfully reach and encourage under-represented populations (including South Asians) to join the bone marrow registry?
Yes, this concept will resonate with diverse groups of people from all over the world.
No, this concept might not reach under-represented populations very well.
I'm not sure, but I hope so!
How well does this concept dispel myths, ease fears, or provide education about bone marrow registration and donation?
Really well -- I already feel like I have a better understanding of the process and why it's important.
Okay, though it'll still take some explaining to get people to understand how bone marrow registration and donation work.
Not very well -- we'd have to create a highly detailed plan around this concept to help people understand.
How scalable is this concept?
This concept is highly scalable and could easily impact people all over the world.
This concept is really best suited for small groups and local areas.
This concept could be scaled, but we'd have to refine it for different settings.

ever_been_bored_at_an_airport.description: Airlines possess the opportunity to weave bone marrow donation into rewards programs to develop a deep emotional connection with its customers, drive sales, increase customer loyalty, enhance brand value and save lives.
ever_been_bored_at_an_airport.creator: ad570fa32ab427aa8f34f366862a330e

comments.text: great idea. i agree with jennifer that most people would be thinking of nothing other than being done waiting. they'll probably feel bored perhaps annoyed too (think of delayed flights!). i do agree that this could be a great opp -- people have time at their disposal to register. i think key is to uplift people's mood (some sort of surprise/happy events); change of mood translates into higher chance of charitable acts.

A fascinating way to target specific populations.  But I'm wondering how intrusive it will feel, since folks waiting at an airport seem to want to think of nothing other than getting where they want to go.  I would suggest that if there were some sort of airport campaign, it be done using sleek and inspirational travel-related themes, like transporting recipients to their healthy destinations (I'm no marketer but you get the idea).  Keep it related to the context.I'm not sure about creating incentive with flight miles or upgrades.  Since a person can only register once, it's not likely they'd get enough miles to do anything with it, so they wouldn't care.  Upgrades is interesting but I've rarely seen a flight these days with extra first or business class seats.  Perhaps just keep it altruistic.  Lastly, I absolutely love the idea of a screen that shows metrics about how many people have gotten their cheek swabbed.  Maybe it could compare live stats from different gates, terminals, or airlines.  That would certainly pique interest, and -- as participation accrues -- may even quell some fears about getting swabbed.  Like "everybody's doing it."
Kris, great inspiration...I had an idea along these lines....check it out and let em knwo your thoughts- http://bit.ly/gahaZU

animation._a_learning_tool..description:
People can get in touch with the needs and difficulties in a ludic way. Animation movies (Pixar is the benchmark or could be the producer) can communicate without being boring, educate without being paternalist.

comments.text: Love this idea - making a connection through a cartoon is great.On a real tangent (but hope you see the value!), it reminds me of the 'Habbit' character you can make of yourself to see how much carbon you use. http://www.changinghabbits.co.uk/  It creates a disfigured character of yourself related to your energy use habits. could the character/animation play on certains areas that people don't necessarily associate with bone marrow issues?

I enjoy this idea a lot too! I had also thought that an animation would be a good way to put a friendly face on the actual, physical process of donation. Creating a pleasant animation with a silly character (getting blood drawn, getting an injection) might be easier to take than reading about it or seeing images of a real human. Also, I would suggest that even though a cute animation connects with kids, it's likely to be appealing to many adults as well. (think Finding Nemo)

What a nice way to make the topic of bone marrow donation a little less scary, especially for kids! Makes me think a bit about Fernanda's post re: teaching kids at an early age http://bit.ly/dHjzsM. Maybe there's a way to connect the two of these to create a concept around using animation to engage school children?

py/tuple: How easy is this concept to implement?
I could start right now.
This might take a bit of planning and probably some help from several partners.
This is a big undertaking and I'd need a lot of help from friends, organizations and other groups to make it happen.
Will this concept successfully reach and encourage under-represented populations (including South Asians) to join the bone marrow registry?
Yes, this concept will resonate with diverse groups of people from all over the world.
No, this concept might not reach under-represented populations very well.
I'm not sure, but I hope so!
How well does this concept dispel myths, ease fears, or provide education about bone marrow registration and donation?
Really well -- I already feel like I have a better understanding of the process and why it's important.
Okay, though it'll still take some explaining to get people to understand how bone marrow registration and donation work.
Not very well -- we'd have to create a highly detailed plan around this concept to help people understand.
How scalable is this concept?
This concept is highly scalable and could easily impact people all over the world.
This concept is really best suited for small groups and local areas.
This concept could be scaled, but we'd have to refine it for different settings.

bones_without_borders.description: Utilize and partner up with existing international medical aid organizations/NGOs like Doctors Without Borders, Red Cross, WHO, etc. to use their resources to get more donors internationally and create more stable access to donors when needed.  While doing checkups or providing general care, they can both inform and appeal for bone marrow donors.
bones_without_borders.creator: a1e991dcff2a10a49b8e765d1ea4a0ee

comments.text: Really nice concept, Jordan, and great discussion here in the comments!To build further, I wonder what else we could think about to address some of Thiele's concerns? Ideas like providing education in local languages, looking at existing infrastructure/supply chains to get bone marrow donations to people in need quickly, or leveraging the local reputations of volunteer physicians to foster trust? It would be great to push this concept to the next level by thinking through how we might address these types of questions.

Thanks for your comment.  First of all, I certainly agree that this should not be a one way street, but the concept is not designed to focus on that.  Rather, it's designed to increase awareness and registration of donors in previously untapped populations.  Secondly, aid is very complex.  There are certainly arguments for its harming nationalism, but I would be careful about making blanket statements.  Moreover, I think this is more of a danger with nation sponsored aid groups as opposed to international aid groups which focus on medical treatment, which have often crossed the divide and are less likely to cause concern and in fact are less likely to try to cheat the nation for their own political gains (the very reason such groups are allowed inside nations when other aid is not).  As for need, the challengers themselves pointed to the need in such nations being the most dire.  I think that the need is more known in developed countries, simply because we have better and more diagnoses of cancer and more knowledge that bone marrow transplants would be helpful.  I don't think that this points to less need, simply less awareness of the need.I definitely agree that the infrastructure for bone marrow is not necessarily available to the degree it needs to be in such countries.  This is not a reason to not try, rather I see it as a challenge that needs to be addressed in conjunction with this solution to allow it to have actual effect.  I'll definitely think on this piece of it and how we could increase such infrastructure in the countries.  As for the "bone marrow vampires," keep in mind that this is not by any means a forced program, but rather completely voluntary.  Not only that, but local reputations and relationships, as well as experience in dealing with cultural concerns should allow such groups to have a better shot to avoid such labels.  But, I agree this is definitely a concern with any outside aid.  I hope that clarifies the concept a bit and addresses your major concerns.  I realize that this idea is not perfect, but when looking to increase bone marrow donation in the context of lesser developed nations, I think we will find it very hard to find such a perfect solution and must settle for what we can. I will continue to think on your concerns and how to modify based on them.

The principle of international medical aid organizations is humanitarian aid, isn't it ?That is more or less north helping south, "rich" helping "poor", asking nothing in exchange.Why not a "north-south" exchange ?International aid harms nationalism : many times we have see countries, local authorities being reluctant in accepting international aid.Perhaps it could help to solve that problem, but it could also kill medical aid based on generousity. What medical aid NGO think of this ?To avoid this problem you should insure that alocation of bone marrow between developed and undeveloped countries is fair.I think that needs for bone marrow are higher in developped countries than in undeveloped countries, but i'm not completely sure.What i know is that infrastructure for bone marrow treatments is mainly based in developed countries. And that bone marrow sample hardly survive more than 24 hours : an african marrow donor living in a small village, for example, will have to travel long distance to reach a town or even a country, otherwise he would have no chance to go if it was to receive a treatment.Your idea is'nt bad, but you must be very careful, to avoid that medical aid NGO began locally perceived as "bone marrow vampires".How to guarantee good level of education / information to avoid local populations being eventually cheated ?How to guarantee a fair exchange between developed and undeveloped countries while maintaining the generosity basis ?Hoping that my comments will help you.

bones_without_borders.title: Bone Marrow Without Borders
